Authors: Carlos B., Alvaro D.B., Freddy K., Eduardo P., Gianfranco P., Franco S.
Title: GEULMóvil - Real-time ultraviolet radiation index mobile network
Source title: Conference Record - IEEE Instrumentation and Measurement Technology Conference
Affiliations: Nucleo de Ingenieria Biomedica de Las Facultades de Ingenieria y Medicina, Departamento de Medicina, Universidad de la República y Hospital Pasteur, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Carlos, B., Nucleo de Ingenieria Biomedica de Las Facultades de Ingenieria y Medicina, Departamento de Medicina, Universidad de la República y Hospital Pasteur, Montevideo, Uruguay; Alvaro, D.B., Nucleo de Ingenieria Biomedica de Las Facultades de Ingenieria y Medicina, Departamento de Medicina, Universidad de la República y Hospital Pasteur, Montevideo, Uruguay; Freddy, K., Nucleo de Ingenieria Biomedica de Las Facultades de Ingenieria y Medicina, Departamento de Medicina, Universidad de la República y Hospital Pasteur, Montevideo, Uruguay; Eduardo, P., Nucleo de Ingenieria Biomedica de Las Facultades de Ingenieria y Medicina, Departamento de Medicina, Universidad de la República y Hospital Pasteur, Montevideo, Uruguay; Gianfranco, P., Nucleo de Ingenieria Biomedica de Las Facultades de Ingenieria y Medicina, Departamento de Medicina, Universidad de la República y Hospital Pasteur, Montevideo, Uruguay; Franco, S., Nucleo de Ingenieria Biomedica de Las Facultades de Ingenieria y Medicina, Departamento de Medicina, Universidad de la República y Hospital Pasteur, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: GEULMóvil captures real-time solar ultraviolet radiation index (UVI), from moving vehicles. For the first time, geographically referenced UVI radiation is measured from the earth as opposed to indirect satellite UVI estimation. Time stamped UVI, along with GPS data, is included in a standard SMS message sent to a server. A web application displays real time UVI maps. GEULMóvil consists of a UVI sensor, a GPS, a modem and is designed around an Arduino. GEULMóvil has an estimated cost below U$S 1000, in small quantities. GEULMóvil allows to be reprogrammed remotely for administration and maintenance. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Badán J.A., Marotti R.E., Dalchiele E.A., Ariosa D., Martín F., Leinen D., Ramos-Barrado J.R.
Title: Optical characterization of Si nanowires: Dependence with substrate orientation and light polarization
Source title: Materials Research Society Symposium Proceedings
Affiliations: Instituto de Física and CINQUIFIMA, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Julio H. Reissig 565, CC 30, Montevideo, Uruguay; Lab. de Materiales y Superficies (Unidad Asociada Al CSIC), Dptos. de Física Aplicada and Ingeniería Química, Universidad de Málaga, Campus de Teatinos s/n, Málaga, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Badán, J.A., Instituto de Física and CINQUIFIMA, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Julio H. Reissig 565, CC 30, Montevideo, Uruguay; Marotti, R.E., Instituto de Física and CINQUIFIMA, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Julio H. Reissig 565, CC 30, Montevideo, Uruguay; Dalchiele, E.A., Instituto de Física and CINQUIFIMA, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Julio H. Reissig 565, CC 30, Montevideo, Uruguay; Ariosa, D., Instituto de Física and CINQUIFIMA, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Julio H. Reissig 565, CC 30, Montevideo, Uruguay; Martín, F., Lab. de Materiales y Superficies (Unidad Asociada Al CSIC), Dptos. de Física Aplicada and Ingeniería Química, Universidad de Málaga, Campus de Teatinos s/n, Málaga, Spain; Leinen, D., Lab. de Materiales y Superficies (Unidad Asociada Al CSIC), Dptos. de Física Aplicada and Ingeniería Química, Universidad de Málaga, Campus de Teatinos s/n, Málaga, Spain; Ramos-Barrado, J.R., Lab. de Materiales y Superficies (Unidad Asociada Al CSIC), Dptos. de Física Aplicada and Ingeniería Química, Universidad de Málaga, Campus de Teatinos s/n, Málaga, Spain
Abstract: Optical properties of Si nanowire arrays (SiNWs) prepared on p-doped Si(111) and Si(100) substrates are studied. The SiNWs were synthesized by self-assembly electroless metal deposition nanoelectrochemistry in an ionic silver HF solution through selective etching. Total reflectance (Rt) and total diffuse reflectance (Rdt) of SiNWs change drastically in comparison to polished Si. To understand these changes diffuse reflectance (Rd) with polarized incident light was studied. For samples prepared on Si(111), the wavelength integrated Rd (wIRd) shows maxima at certain angle of incidence θ and it does not depend on light polarization. Moreover, Rdt of SiNWs prepared on Si(111) can be modeled as an ensemble of diffuse reflectors. For samples prepared on Si(100) wIRd increases with θ, being greater when the light electric field is parallel to the plane of incidence. Also, Rd spectra show structures due to interference effects. For these reasons SiNWs prepared on Si(100) can be considered as a thin film whose refractive index depends on light polarization. © 2014 Materials Research Society.

Authors: Montandon C.A., Introini L.V., Thomas J.E.S.
Title: Searchable encryption through dispersion
Source title: Proceedings of the 2014 IEEE Central America and Panama Convention, CONCAPAN 2014
Affiliations: Universidad Católica Del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Montandon, C.A., Universidad Católica Del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay; Introini, L.V., Universidad Católica Del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay; Thomas, J.E.S., Universidad Católica Del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Cryptography is the universal tool to protect the privacy of data. Today's cryptography still requires encrypted data to be decrypted before it can be searched. We propose here an alternative way of protecting the privacy of data through dispersion of a compressed version of the original data that can be searched without recovering the original data. Our scheme compresses the original data and then generates several chunks that are stored at different nodes. The chunks are stored in the form of an index. To search for a string, we convert the string into chunks with the same scheme and then have each site consult its index in order to obtain a list of all possible positions where the search string might be found. These local results are then sent to the user who performs a logical intersection to find all likely positions in the original, where the search string might be located in the text. The user can then decrypt only those parts or records to obtain all parts or records where the search string is. Our scheme has no false negatives (all occurrences of the search string will be found). We show that the precision becomes close to 100% for longer strings using a corpus consisting of texts in the English language. We also show that the chunks are somewhat, but not quite similar to random bit streams, and that each individual stream has less information content than a typical English language stream of the same length. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Suárez-Bagnasco D., Balay G., Cymberknop L., Armentano R.L., Negreira C.
Title: In vitro high resolution ultrasonography measurements of arterial bifurcations with and without stenosis as inputs for in-silico CFD simulations
Source title: IFMBE Proceedings
Affiliations: Laboratorio de Acústica Ultrasonora, Instituto de Física, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Departamento de Electrónica, Universidad Tecnológica Nacional, Argentina; Departamento de Fisiología, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Suárez-Bagnasco, D., Laboratorio de Acústica Ultrasonora, Instituto de Física, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Balay, G., Laboratorio de Acústica Ultrasonora, Instituto de Física, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Cymberknop, L., Departamento de Electrónica, Universidad Tecnológica Nacional, Argentina; Armentano, R.L., Departamento de Fisiología, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Negreira, C., Laboratorio de Acústica Ultrasonora, Instituto de Física, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Quantification of fluid-structure interactions in arterial walls requires to achieve a complete characterization of flow, shear stress in the interface between blood and endothelium, wall elasticity and wall stresses distribution. Diameter change vs. intravascular pressure is the basis to estimate biomechanical properties (e.g. elasticity, viscosity) of arterial walls in-vivo or in-vitro, being sonomicrometry the gold standard for vessel diameter measurement. High resolution ultrasonography (HRU) is used here in-vitro (as an alternative to sonomicrometry) to get an adequate estimation of the diameter without disturbing the vessel dynamics. Some experimental in-vitro results are shown for a physical model of arterial bifurcation surgically implemented from a sample of fresh porcine aorta, with and without asymmetric stenosis. Near-physiologic pulsated flow conditions were reproduced in-vitro using a specially designed hemodynamic work bench simulator (HWBS). In-silico results obtained from a simple CFD model of the abovementioned bifurcation are presented. Boundary conditions were applied from in-vitro HWBS experimental measurements. Levels of stenosis were reproduced in-silico. Properly tuned digital simulation based on in-vitro experimental data using our HWBS allows the determination of physical magnitudes (like shear stress) that can't be obtained easily in experimental in-vitro measurements. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.

Authors: Izquierdo D., Faverio C., Garcia A., Trigo L., Slomovitz D.
Title: Inductance comparator bridge
Source title: CPEM Digest (Conference on Precision Electromagnetic Measurements)
Affiliations: UTE Laboratory, Montevideo, Uruguay

Abstract: This paper proposes a new inductance bridge to compare decade standard inductors in ratios 11 and 110. This allows to calibrate a complete set of standard inductors from only one inductor externally calibrated, and to test linearity errors in conventional inductance bridges between 10% and 100% of each range. © 2014 IEEE.

Title: On the fast transient spoiler deployment in a NACA0012 profile using LES techniques combined with AMR and IMB methods
Source title: 11th World Congress on Computational Mechanics, WCCM 2014, 5th European Conference on Computational Mechanics, ECCM 2014 and 6th European Conference on Computational Fluid Dynamics, ECFD 2014
Affiliations: Heat and Mass Transfer Technological Center, Polytechnical University of Catalonia (UPC), Colom 11, Terrassa, Barcelona, Spain; Instituto de Ingeniería Mecánica y Producción Industrial, Universidad de la Repúbilica del Uruguay (UdelaR), Av. 18 de Julio 1968, Montevideo, Uruguay; Termo Fluids, S.L., Avda. Jaquard, 97 1-E, Terrassa (Barcelona), Spain
Authors with affiliations: Favre, F., Heat and Mass Transfer Technological Center, Polytechnical University of Catalonia (UPC), Colom 11, Terrassa, Barcelona, Spain, Instituto de Ingeniería Mecánica y Producción Industrial, Universidad de la Repúbilica del Uruguay (UdelaR), Av. 18 de Julio 1968, Montevideo, Uruguay; Antepara, O., Heat and Mass Transfer Technological Center, Polytechnical University of Catalonia (UPC), Colom 11, Terrassa, Barcelona, Spain; Lehmkuhl, O., Heat and Mass Transfer Technological Center, Polytechnical University of Catalonia (UPC), Colom 11, Terrassa, Barcelona, Spain, Termo Fluids, S.L., Avda. Jaquard, 97 1-E, Terrassa (Barcelona), Spain; Borrell, R., Termo Fluids, S.L., Avda. Jaquard, 97 1-E, Terrassa (Barcelona), Spain; Oliva, A., Heat and Mass Transfer Technological Center, Polytechnical University of Catalonia (UPC), Colom 11, Terrassa, Barcelona, Spain
Abstract: Due to the high impact in final cost reduction, the development of active systems of load control for wind turbines has recently gained renewed interest. The use of these systems results in a faster and more detailed action over the blade's load than modern pitch-control systems, using aerodynamic control surfaces to locally modify the flux. Numerical simulations of these fluxes are presented in this work as a powerful tool for its understanding. A combination of large-eddy simulations (LES) techniques and the immersed-boundary method was employed in order to meet the conditions imposed by the mobile parts of the control systems embedded in the computational mesh. Use was also made of the Adaptive Mesh Refinement (AMR) method presented in [1] to minimize the amount of computational cells and therefore obtain an adequate resolution of the different length scales. A simulation of the experiment presented by Yeung et al. [2] was performed as a validation of the proposed model. The experiment consists of an aerodynamic profile deploying a control-surface with a Re=3,5×105 flux.

Authors: Mercelis P., Dufour M., Gebelin A.A., Gruwez V., Doorme S., Sas M., Leyssen G.
Title: Generation of multivariate wave conditions as input for a probabilistic level III breakwater design
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Offshore Mechanics and Arctic Engineering - OMAE
Affiliations: IMDC, Antwerp, Belgium; GDF Suez, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Gas Sayago, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Mercelis, P., IMDC, Antwerp, Belgium; Dufour, M., GDF Suez, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Gebelin, A.A., Gas Sayago, Montevideo, Uruguay; Gruwez, V., IMDC, Antwerp, Belgium; Doorme, S., IMDC, Antwerp, Belgium; Sas, M., IMDC, Antwerp, Belgium; Leyssen, G., IMDC, Antwerp, Belgium
Abstract: For an offshore LNG project situated in the estuary of the Rio de la Plata nearby Montevideo, Uruguay, it was required to verify the deterministic design of the protective rubble mound breakwater and the jetty infrastructure with a level three probabilistic design. Therefore, in first instance extreme site conditions were required both in front of and behind the breakwater. To obtain these conditions, the first step is to extrapolate the offshore variables in order to translate them to the breakwater location. All the possible combinations of extreme wind, water level and waves are quantified with a probability of occurrence. A combination of univariate extreme value distributions, copula's and regression is used to describe the multivariate statistical behaviour of the offshore variables. The main variable is the wind velocity, as in the area of concern extreme wave conditions are wind driven. The secondary variable is water level. Wind velocity and water levels are only correlated for some wind directions. For these directions, wind velocity and water level extreme value distributions are linked through a multivariate Gumbel Copula. The wave height at the model boundaries was taken into account by a regression function with the extreme wind velocity at the offshore location and the wave period by a regression function with the wave height. This way 1515 synthetic events were selected and simulated with the spectral wave model SWAN, each of which a frequency of occurrence is calculated for. However, due to refraction and diffraction effects of the approach channel (in the area of concern water depths are limited to about 7 m and the navigation channel has a depth of about 14 m), the port basin and the breakwater itself, the spectral wave model SWAN is not sufficient to accurately calculate the local wave conditions in the entire area of interest. Therefore a non-linear Boussinesq wave model (i.e. Mike 21 BW) was set up in addition, using input from the spectral model at the boundary and including the navigation channel of more than 12 km long. Combining both models, significant wave heights are obtained on both the seaward side and the leeside of the breakwater with corresponding frequencies of occurrence. This approach allows the determination of conditional return periods and generates the site conditions required for a probabilistic level three design of the breakwater and the jetty infrastructure taking for example the joint probabilities between waves and water levels fully into account as needed for overtopping or failure calculations. Copyright © 2014 by ASME.

Authors: Pereyra C.J., Ferrer F., Marotti R.E., Gómez C., Campo L., Amy L.I., Martín F., Leinen D., Ramos-Barrado J.R., Dalchiele E.A.
Title: Optical properties of CdS and CdTe sensitized ZnO nanorods
Source title: Materials Research Society Symposium Proceedings
Affiliations: Instituto de Física and CINQUIFIMA, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Lab. de Materiales y Superficies (Unidad Asociada Al CSIC), Dptos. de Física Aplicada and Ingeniería Química, Universidad de Málaga, Campus de Teatinos s/n, Málaga, Spain

Abstract: Optical properties of ZnO-CdTe electrochemically prepared on a core-shell nanostructure (NS) were studied. Numerical simulations based on effective medium approximation give higher absorption than ZnO-CdS samples and a sensitive dependence on CdTe content. The absorption edges for deep black samples found by transmittance (T(λ)) and diffuse reflectance (R diff (λ)) measurements were at 1.33eV and 1.55eV, respectively. A split-off band edge was also found by R diff (λ) at ∼2.5eV. The red shift observed in T(λ), previously observed in ZnO-CdS, and may confirm the enhancement of sub-bandgap absorption due to the NS nature of samples. Copyright © 2014 Materials Research Society.

Authors: Solari S., Losada M.T.
Title: Comments on "Point-in-time and extreme-value probability simulation technique for engineering design", by R. Minguez, Y. Guanche and F. Méndez [Structural Safety Vol. 41 pp. 29-36, 2013]
Source title: Structural Safety
Affiliations: Universidad de República, Instituto de Mecánica de los Fluidos e Ingeniería Ambiental (IMFIA), J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo 11300, Uruguay; Universidad de Granada, Instituto Interuniversitario de Investigación del Sistema Tierra en Andalucía (IIISTA), Av. del Mediterráneo s/n Edificio CEAMA, Granada 18006, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Solari, S., Universidad de República, Instituto de Mecánica de los Fluidos e Ingeniería Ambiental (IMFIA), J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo 11300, Uruguay; Losada, M.T., Universidad de Granada, Instituto Interuniversitario de Investigación del Sistema Tierra en Andalucía (IIISTA), Av. del Mediterráneo s/n Edificio CEAMA, Granada 18006, Spain
Abstract: Mínguez et al. (2013) [. 1] proposed a method, (a) to characterize and to combine graphically both the point-in-time and extreme-value probability distribution, (b) to apply Monte Carlo simulation technique to reproduce both regimes, and (3) to use their distributions in the frame of first order reliability methods (FORM). This discussion is to comment on the limited validity of the proposed method. Firstly, the method should formally include the extremal index in the relationships between the distribution functions. Moreover, it is only valid if the data are independents and there is no autocorrelation or it is negative. To provide additional information related with the discussion, two new set of data are worked out: (1) significant wave height obtained in the Gulf of Cádiz (hindcast data, WANA 1952046) with extremal index 0.32, and (2) a simulated series with an ARMA model, autoregressive coefficient 0.95, zero moving average coefficient and an extremal index equal to 0.3. © 2014 Elsevier Ltd.

Authors: Artigue A.
Title: Low-dimensional homoclinic bifurcations of repellers
Source title: International Journal of Bifurcation and Chaos
Affiliations: Departamento de Matemática y Estadí Stica Del Litoral, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Artigue, A., Departamento de Matemática y Estadí Stica Del Litoral, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Abstract: We study the relationship between homoclinic orbits associated with repellers, usually called snap-back repellers, and expanding sets of smooth endomorphisms. We also consider critical homoclinic orbits and prove that the bifurcations they create constitute a codimension one phenomenon. This and other possible routes to the creation of homoclinic orbits are considered in low dimensions. © 2014 World Scientific Publishing Company.

Authors: Aristoy G., Santos A., Arabadjian H., Slomovitz D.
Title: Burden influence on measuring transformers calibration
Source title: CPEM Digest (Conference on Precision Electromagnetic Measurements)
Affiliations: UTE, Laboratory, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Aristoy, G., UTE, Laboratory, Montevideo, Uruguay; Santos, A., UTE, Laboratory, Montevideo, Uruguay; Arabadjian, H., UTE, Laboratory, Montevideo, Uruguay; Slomovitz, D., UTE, Laboratory, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: This paper analyzes the effect of the burden on the errors of measuring transformers, specifically the influence of the power factor. Standards propose to calibrate these measuring devices using burdens with different power factor, from 0.1 to 1, but nowadays usual working conditions impose unity power factor in all cases. Error variations due to the power factor of the burden have been measured in a set of different high voltage current and voltage measuring transformers used for energy billing systems. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Brum P.
Title: Revisiting Urban Guerrillas: Armed Propaganda and the Insurgency of Uruguay's MLN-Tupamaros, 1969-70
Source title: Studies in Conflict and Terrorism
Affiliations: Universidad ORT Uruguay, Departamento de Estudios Internacionales, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Brum, P., Universidad ORT Uruguay, Departamento de Estudios Internacionales, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: This article studies a singular aspect of the urban insurgency of Uruguay's MLN-Tupamaros: the tactic of armed propaganda. The Tupamaros applied the method mainly at the peak of their existence, in the years 1969-70. Afterward they opted predominantly for others, such as terrorism. By comparing the two periods, I argue that armed propaganda helped the organization to thrive, while the latter was an important cause of its demise. The conclusion suggests that armed propaganda led the Tupamaros to significant accomplishments, but also that switching tactics was a major determinant in their defeat. © 2014 Copyright © Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors with affiliations: Carranza, R., Centro Nacional de Metrología México, Mexico; Campos, S., Centro Nacional de Metrología México, Mexico; Castruita, A., Centro Nacional de Metrología México, Mexico; Nelson, T., National Institute of Standards and Technology, United States; Ribeiro, A., Instituto Nacional de Metrologia, Qualidade e Tecnologia, Brazil; So, E., National Research Council of Canada, Canada; Di Lillo, L., Instituto Nacional de Tecnología Industrial, Argentina; Spaggiari, A., Administración Nacional de Usinas y Transmisiones Eléctricas, Uruguay; Slomovitz, D., Administración Nacional de Usinas y Transmisiones Eléctricas, Uruguay; Izquierdo, D., Administración Nacional de Usinas y Transmisiones Eléctricas, Uruguay; Faverio, C., Administración Nacional de Usinas y Transmisiones Eléctricas, Uruguay; Postigo, H., Instituto Nacional de Defensa de la Competencia y de la Proteccion de la Propiedad Intelectual, Peru; Sanchez, H., Instituto Costarricense de Electricidad, Costa Rica; Gonzalez, J., Centro Nacional de Metrología de Panamá, Panama; Porras, G., Instituto Nacional de Metrología de Colombia, Colombia
Abstract: From years 2010 to 2012, a key comparison of power standards at 50/60 Hz was conducted in the SIM region. The comparison included measurements of active and reactive power at three frequencies, aiming at providing support to high accuracy measurement needs of reactive power. This paper presents the results of the SIM.EM-K5 comparison and the assessment of the link between this comparison and the CCEM-K5 key comparison on 50/60 Hz power completed in 2001. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Kaukiainen J., Lasslett N., Goulimis C., Gomez L.
Title: Benefits of optimisation based production scheduling within integrated pulp and paper operations
Source title: Fibre Value Chain Conference and Expo 2014: Pulp and Paper Bioenergy Bioproducts
Affiliations: Greycon Ltd., Valtatie 12, Kouvola, Finland; Procex Pty Ltd, 39 Balmoral Avenue, Brunswick East, Australia; Greycon Ltd., 7 Calico House, Plantation Wharf, York Road, London, United Kingdom; Greycon Ltd., Javier de Viana 2384, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Kaukiainen, J., Greycon Ltd., Valtatie 12, Kouvola, Finland; Lasslett, N., Procex Pty Ltd, 39 Balmoral Avenue, Brunswick East, Australia; Goulimis, C., Greycon Ltd., 7 Calico House, Plantation Wharf, York Road, London, United Kingdom; Gomez, L., Greycon Ltd., Javier de Viana 2384, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: This paper will discuss the relevance of the optimisation-based production scheduling for pulp and paper processes. Remarkable benefits are available when managing production planning and optimisation with a modern IT system supporting global optimisation-based scheduling. The implementation effort for such systems is now quite modest. Even in a modern integrated pulp and papermill employing high quality automation systems, the production schedule is typically crafted in a manual or semi-manual fashion, unsupported by a global constraint model that considers all of the day-today operating issues. Customers' orders are aggregated into paper type families and typically the top-level addresses the block schedule at the paper machine. Taking this as an input, the planner tries to schedule the pulp production resources (mainly the digesters). In order to find a feasible solution, various iterations between the two levels are conducted based on different feedback mechanisms. In this process, feasibility is placed over optimality, leading to suboptimal production plans and schedules. Nevertheless significant improvement is possible when combining optimalplans with feasible execution within day-to-day operation. Lasslett has earlier observed that production at different bottlenecks in a mill would need to be maximised, but not at any cost. He suggests that the rest of the mill must also be coordinated with precise planning to ensure that not only the maximum production takes place at the bottlenecks, but also costs are minimised and the whole mill should be best prepared to deal with unplanned events at any time. Given the situation with existing methods of manual planning and scheduling, various studies suggest there is non-trivial potential for improvement simply by the introduction of a tool for optimisation based scheduling. Mills, where production constraints are dynamic and pulp production is directly linked with the block schedule of paper machines, are the ones which have the most potential for improvement. However, other pulp producers can also benefit. The concept, although not new, has been difficult to introduce in the past. This problem has been recently solved in a practical manner. It is now possible for the scheduling system to calculate the production schedules for modelled pulp mill processes and storage tanks dynamically. The paper and presentation will discuss this in detail. Although the amount of data required from various information points remains high, with OPC and other modern integration technologies, existing process data collection technology is up to the task. The upfront investment required to make the scheduling system work for an integrated mill is small compared to the benefits, and thus the return on investment (ROI) can be in months, sometimes even weeks.

Authors: David M., Golberg R., Rubinsky B.
Title: Magnetic induction of electroporation: Numerical analysis and technical limitations
Source title: 2014 36th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society, EMBC 2014
Affiliations: Electronics Engineering Department, Azrieli College of Engineering, Israel; Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel; Núcleo de Ingeniería Biomédica, Uruguay; Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: David, M., Electronics Engineering Department, Azrieli College of Engineering, Israel, Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Israel, Núcleo de Ingeniería Biomédica, Uruguay; Golberg, R., Electronics Engineering Department, Azrieli College of Engineering, Israel; Rubinsky, B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States
Abstract: Electric fields delivered across biological cells can cause structural and functional changes to the cell membrane, such as electroporation. An important application of electroporation is in the permeabilization of skin cells. Currently these cells are electroporated with contact electrodes. In this study we explore the feasibility of using electromagnetic induction for non-contact electroporation of skin cells, and the effect of various design parameters on the process. We derived a simple analytical solution that lends itself to a systematic study of design parameters and verified the solution with a numeric solution of the Maxwell equations using finite elements. A short feasibility study of the system implementation is done, concluding that there are technological limitations that must be met in the future in order to build such a device. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Mateo R., Tanco M., Santos J.
Title: Less expert workers and customer complaints: Automotive case study
Source title: Human Factors and Ergonomics In Manufacturing
Affiliations: School of Economics and Business Administration, University of Navarra, Navarra, Spain; Industrial Management Department, TECNUN, University of Navarra, Paseo Manuel Lardiźabal 13, 20018, Gipuzcoa, Spain; CiTEM, Universidad de Montevideo, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Mateo, R., School of Economics and Business Administration, University of Navarra, Navarra, Spain; Tanco, M., Industrial Management Department, TECNUN, University of Navarra, Paseo Manuel Lardiźabal 13, 20018, Gipuzcoa, Spain, CiTEM, Universidad de Montevideo, Montevideo, Uruguay; Santos, J., Industrial Management Department, TECNUN, University of Navarra, Paseo Manuel Lardiźabal 13, 20018, Gipuzcoa, Spain
Abstract: Many researchers consider absenteeism to be a significant problem for employers. Absenteeism lowers the overall level of worker expertise, which may affect product quality and trigger an increase in customer complaints. This research was carried out in a prominent automobile manufacturing company, with an assembly line-driven rigid production process. This article gathered customer quality complaints registered during the 17 months after cars were delivered to customers, from one year of car production, to analyze how employee absenteeism affects customer quality complaints. The empirical evidence presented by this research in the automotive industry confirms that absenteeism does not lead, necessarily, to a decrease in quality. This evidence must make organization redefine the value of their expert workers. Moreover, these results could have an impact on assembly-line design and the use of worker job-rotation programs for technologically sophisticated assembly lines. © 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc. © 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.

Authors: Ramos J.A., Osorio M., Belsterli G., Frins E., Barreto M.
Title: Differential Optical Absorption Spectroscopy system for multi purpose applications
Source title: Conference Record - IEEE Instrumentation and Measurement Technology Conference
Affiliations: Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Ramos, J.A., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Osorio, M., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Belsterli, G., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Frins, E., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Barreto, M., Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Topographic Target Light scattering - Differential Optical Absorption Spectroscopy (ToTAL-DOAS) is a novel atmospheric monitoring technique to obtain atmospheric trace gas concentrations from scattered sunlight measurements. The main issue to successfully apply this method is the need of a telescope to identify the targets clearly and efficiently couple light in a spectrometer. Also the need of measurements with different logistic requirements (e.g. from different platforms as from mobile, airborne, vessels, etc) it is of benefit to develop a new optical system for data acquisition. There are two key aspects to take into account: One of them is the importance to preserve a constant temperature on the spectrometer's CCD. The second key aspect is to have a standalone unit which can be attached to different telescopes or to other optical devices in order to confront different experimental situations, and to be able to measure different optical parameters without the hassle of being concerned about the reliability of the spectrometer's condition. Specifically, the aim of our work was to build a standalone hermetic housing for an Ocean Optics 2000+ spectrometer with temperature stabilization and portability. In this paper a description of the DOAS-System is presented as well as the results of preliminary test measurements by monitoring the trace gases SO2 and NO2 measured at the city of Montevideo. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Thomasset P.J.
Title: Accurate DC-DC power converters as hydro turbine speed governor power supply
Source title: Conference Record - IEEE Instrumentation and Measurement Technology Conference
Affiliations: C.H. Dr. G. Terra Power Plant Maintenance Manager, UTE, Rincón-del-Bonete, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Thomasset, P.J., C.H. Dr. G. Terra Power Plant Maintenance Manager, UTE, Rincón-del-Bonete, Uruguay
Abstract: Hydro power plant electronic speed governor are engineering customized designs, as high accurate and reliable as possible. The DC-DC power converter used as multiple voltage power supply, must have at least the same reliability of the governor itself, to avoid frequently failures and turbine emergency shutdowns. Project design and final user right equipment maintenance, play a main role in reliability and service life. All this is what the standard IEEE 1573-2003 calls the Environmental Interface and Environmental Interface Adaptation. An example of a power supply series of failures, lead to specifying new power converters, and how this changed the number of hydro turbine shutdown statistics. A case study of an hydro power plant is described. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Martinez J.G., Ramos-Becerril F.J., Leija L., Lopez F., Garcia U., Vera A., Negreira C.
Title: Development of an electronic equipment for the pre medical diagnose in the progress of diabetic foot disease
Source title: Proceedings - 2014 International Conference on Control, Decision and Information Technologies, CoDIT 2014
Affiliations: Instituto Nacional de Rehabilitación, México DF, Mexico; Bioelectronics Section, CINVESTAV-IPN, México D.F., Mexico; Universidad de la República de Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Martinez, J.G., Instituto Nacional de Rehabilitación, México DF, Mexico; Ramos-Becerril, F.J., Instituto Nacional de Rehabilitación, México DF, Mexico; Leija, L., Bioelectronics Section, CINVESTAV-IPN, México D.F., Mexico; Lopez, F., Bioelectronics Section, CINVESTAV-IPN, México D.F., Mexico; Garcia, U., Bioelectronics Section, CINVESTAV-IPN, México D.F., Mexico; Vera, A., Bioelectronics Section, CINVESTAV-IPN, México D.F., Mexico; Negreira, C., Universidad de la República de Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: This paper presents an instrument that uses electronic technologies to characterize the effects of diabetes by measuring the changes of the tissue physical characteristics, mainly in the foot. The instrument comprises 1) the measurement of glucose, 2) IR temperature measurement of the foot, 3) the differentiation of staining in areas of the foot, 4) the determination of the elasticity of vessels and foot tissues, 5) the determination of muscle impedance, 6) the recording of the variation of the patient heart rate, 7) software that concentrates the digital information of the measured characteristics of the foot and a display to show the information to the physician. This article describes the results of temperature measurement on the sole of a foot, the patient result storage, a measurement method with RF impedance and the temperature of the foot taken with a commercial IR camera. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Capdehourat G., Larroca F., Belzarena P.
Title: Robust spectrum allocation for cognitive radio networks
Source title: 2014 11th International Symposium on Wireless Communications Systems, ISWCS 2014 - Proceedings
Affiliations: Institute de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Capdehourat, G., Institute de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Larroca, F., Institute de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Belzarena, P., Institute de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Abstract: In recent years we have seen the success of wireless communications in unlicensed frequency bands, mainly driven by the 802.11 standard. The clear trend in the growth of traffic demand suggests that spectrum scarcity will be a serious threat to reach the capacity needs in the near future. Looking for more available spectrum, regulators have already begun to study secondary assignments in licensed bands, based on the recent cognitive network paradigm. In this context, we focus our work in the analysis of optimum spectrum allocation mechanisms. We introduce a stochastic model to formulate the problem, considering primary users' activity and a periodically scheduled assignment scheme. To solve the problem we propose a novel robust solution, which we argue is superior to an expectation based approach, comparing both alternatives through extensive simulations. © 2014 IEEE.

Authors: Ares G.
Title: Cluster analysis: Application in food science and technology
Source title: Mathematical and Statistical Methods in Food Science and Technology
Affiliations: Department of Food Science and Technology, Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Ares, G., Department of Food Science and Technology, Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Cluster analysis is a generic name for a wide range of exploratory multivariate techniques. It is used for classifying a data set in homogeneous groups in an unsupervised situation where little or no a priori information about group structure is available. This chapter focuses on the three most commonly used techniques in food science and technology (hierarchical cluster analysis, k-means and fuzzy clustering), discusses the theory behind the methods and presents examples of application and implementation in R free statistical software. © 2014 by John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Magri Díaz A.J.
Title: The role of housing policies in the systemic efficiency of developing countries: Analysis applied to the Uruguayan experience [El rol de las políticas de vivienda en la eficiencia sistémica de los países en desarrollo: Análisis aplicado a la experiencia en Uruguay]
Source title: Revista INVI
Affiliations: Institute of Political Sciences, University of the Republic, National Agency on Research and Innovation, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Magri Díaz, A.J., Institute of Political Sciences, University of the Republic, National Agency on Research and Innovation, Uruguay
Abstract: This paper analyzes the inclusion of the housing sector in the systemic efficiency of States and applies the case study to the Uruguayan process by scrutinizing the reforms implemented by left-wing governments since 2005. It presents and analyzes the nature of the housing sector, which is defined as systemic due to its impact (in conjunction with the social issue) on the general development of the production and financial systems of a country and its systemic efficiency in relation to the external situation. This paper scrutinizes the different stages involved in the evolution of the systemic integration of housing, which includes the transformation of its social function into a financial and productive function. These policy categories evolved as follows: from the classical (universal) social policies on housing and (targeted) social housing policies defining the role of the State in the production of dwellings, to the recent inclusion of the low-cost housing concept that replicates the experience of other Latin American countries and creates a quasi-housing market that ignores the social issue.

Authors: Joskowicz J., Sotelo R.
Title: Advances in video quality estimation models: An Overview
Source title: IEEE Latin America Transactions
Affiliations: Universidad de la Republica, Uruguay; Universidad de Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Joskowicz, J., Universidad de la Republica, Uruguay; Sotelo, R., Universidad de Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: In recent years many advances and standardizations have been performed in the field of video quality estimation. This paper presents an overview of these recent advances, explaining the main ideas and contributions of the video quality estimation models. The projects of VQEG (Video Quality Experts Group) are discussed, along with the recent standards approved by ITU (International Telecommunication Union), as well as other proposed models by different group of authors. Finally, the future work in this area is outlined. © 2013 IEEE.

Authors: Berrutti F., Giusto A., Artenstein M.
Title: Impact of variable speed wind farms on power systems oscillations
Source title: IEEE Power and Energy Society General Meeting
Affiliations: Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Berrutti, F., Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Giusto, A., Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Artenstein, M., Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Abstract: This paper presents a qualitative development for assess the main factors affecting the damping of the oscillation modes when wind farms based on variable speed turbines are incorporated in power systems. It will be shown that the main effects that determine the degradation or improvement of mode damping due to wind power generation lies in the alteration of the operating points of the involved synchronous generators and the nature of the oscillatory modes affected. It is also analyzed the effect of reactive power exchange between wind farms and the power grid on oscillatory behaviour. Such developments are validated by performing simulations on a 2017 peak scenario for the Uruguayan transmission system, which shows a strong interaction between the pre-existent hydro power plants and future wind farms to be incorporated1. © 2013 IEEE.

Authors: Santos E., Simini F.
Title: Comparison of electrical impedance tomography reconstruction techniques applied to IMPETOM system
Source title: 13th IEEE International Conference on BioInformatics and BioEngineering, IEEE BIBE 2013
Affiliations: Núcleo de Ingeniería Biomédica, Facultades de Medicina e Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Santos, E., Núcleo de Ingeniería Biomédica, Facultades de Medicina e Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Simini, F., Núcleo de Ingeniería Biomédica, Facultades de Medicina e Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Electrical Impedance Tomography (EIT) reconstruction can estimate thorax fluid content. Its use in critically ill patients is promising and may prove clinically useful. Boundary voltages (16-electrode frames) were obtained with our 50 kHz-5 mA IMPETOM system. Comparison of the 492-element Newton-Raphson algorithm with EIDORS open source tool (NOSER & GREIT algorithms), applied to a healthy volunteer, suggests that anatomically adjusted 3D models give better results. Nevertheless for phantom imaging an initial uniform image yields more accurate reconstructions. The results help in the selection and implementation of the reconstruction method for systems similar to IMPETOM. © 2013 IEEE.

Authors: Blejwas J.N.
Title: "Corbusians" in Uruguay: A contradictory report
Source title: Latin American Modern Architectures: Ambiguous Territories
Affiliations: Instituto de Historia de la Arquitectura, Facultad de Arquitectura, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Blejwas, J.N., Instituto de Historia de la Arquitectura, Facultad de Arquitectura, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: Pardo A., Monti G.
Title: Quality of electricity supply in Uruguay: Voltage quality overall regulation and its control experience
Source title: IET Conference Publications
Affiliations: UTE, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Pardo, A., UTE, Uruguay; Monti, G., UTE, Uruguay
Abstract: Since 2006, a control scheme for the Quality of Service of the electric energy distribution was established in Uruguay. The Uruguayan Energy Services Regulator (URSEA), set parameters and goals for all the three Quality of Service aspects: Continuity of Supply, Voltage Quality and Commercial Service Quality. The Administración Nacional de Usinas y Trasmisiones Eléctricas (UTE) is a state-owned enterprise responsible for the Distribution of electricity in all the Uruguayan territory. This paper summarizes UTE's experience in the control of the Voltage Quality aspect after six years of the establishment of this control scheme.

Authors: Tierney D., Frins E., Dultz W., Hils B., Schmitzer H.
Title: Holograms - Made from scratch
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Xavier University, 3800 Victory Parkway, Cincinnati, OH 45207, United States; Instituto de Fisica, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo 11300, Uruguay; University of Frankfurt, Frankfurt a.M. 60054, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Tierney, D., Department of Physics, Xavier University, 3800 Victory Parkway, Cincinnati, OH 45207, United States; Frins, E., Instituto de Fisica, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo 11300, Uruguay; Dultz, W., University of Frankfurt, Frankfurt a.M. 60054, Germany; Hils, B., University of Frankfurt, Frankfurt a.M. 60054, Germany; Schmitzer, H., Department of Physics, Xavier University, 3800 Victory Parkway, Cincinnati, OH 45207, United States
Abstract: Scratch holograms can be described as the limiting case of geometrical optics, where k → ∞ r , in which photons behave like grains of sand. We will show that scratch holograms can in principle be produced and read out by white light interference. © 2013 SPIE.

Authors: Suarez-Bagnasco D., Armentano R.L., Balay G., Negreira C.
Title: An hemodynamic work bench for in-vitro measurements in arterial bifurcations: Experimental results and comparison with the output of a simplified CFD model
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society, EMBS
Affiliations: Laboratorio de Acústica Ultrasonora (LAU), Instituto de Física, Universidad de la República (UdelaR), Montevideo, Uruguay; Departamento de Fisiología, Facultad de Medicina (FMED), Universidad de la República (UdelaR), Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Suarez-Bagnasco, D., Laboratorio de Acústica Ultrasonora (LAU), Instituto de Física, Universidad de la República (UdelaR), Montevideo, Uruguay; Armentano, R.L., Departamento de Fisiología, Facultad de Medicina (FMED), Universidad de la República (UdelaR), Montevideo, Uruguay; Balay, G., Laboratorio de Acústica Ultrasonora (LAU), Instituto de Física, Universidad de la República (UdelaR), Montevideo, Uruguay; Negreira, C., Laboratorio de Acústica Ultrasonora (LAU), Instituto de Física, Universidad de la República (UdelaR), Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: To quantify fluid-structure interactions in arterial walls, from a biomechanical standpoint, a complete characterization of blood flow, shear stress in the interface between blood and endothelium, wall elasticity and wall stresses distribution are needed. © 2013 IEEE.

Authors: Azambuja J.R., Brown G., Kastensmidt F.L., Carro L.
Title: Algorithm transformation methods to reduce software-only fault tolerance techniques' overhead
Source title: Proceedings of the 2013 IEEE 19th International On-Line Testing Symposium, IOLTS 2013
Affiliations: Instituto de Informática, PPGC - PGMICRO, Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do sul (UFRGS), Av. Bento Gonçalves, 9500, Porto Alegre - RS, Brazil; Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Av. 18 de Julio 1968, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Azambuja, J.R., Instituto de Informática, PPGC - PGMICRO, Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do sul (UFRGS), Av. Bento Gonçalves, 9500, Porto Alegre - RS, Brazil; Brown, G., Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Av. 18 de Julio 1968, Montevideo, Uruguay; Kastensmidt, F.L., Instituto de Informática, PPGC - PGMICRO, Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do sul (UFRGS), Av. Bento Gonçalves, 9500, Porto Alegre - RS, Brazil; Carro, L., Instituto de Informática, PPGC - PGMICRO, Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do sul (UFRGS), Av. Bento Gonçalves, 9500, Porto Alegre - RS, Brazil
Abstract: This paper introduces a framework that tackles the costs in area and energy consumed by methodologies like spatial or temporal redundancy with a different approach: given an algorithm, we find a transformation in which part of the computation involved is transformed into memory accesses. The precomputed data stored in memory can be protected then by applying traditional and well established ECC algorithms to provide fault tolerant hardware designs. At the same time, the transformation increases the performance of the system by reducing its execution time, which is then used by customized software-only fault tolerant techniques to protect the system without any degradation when compared to its original form. Application of this technique to key algorithms in a MP3 player, combined with a fault injection campaign, show that this approach increases fault tolerance up to 92%, without any performance degradation. © 2013 IEEE.

Authors: Gamino F., Bazan I., Ramirez A., Ramos A., Negreira C.
Title: Evaluation of high-resolution spectral estimation techniques in tissue thermal characterization under noisy broadband conditions [Evaluación de técnicas de estimación expectral de alta resolución para caracterización termal bajo condiciones de banda-ancha ruidosas]
Source title: Pan American Health Care Exchanges, PAHCE
Affiliations: ESIME ZAC, Instituto Politécnico Nacional, México D.F., Mexico; Ultrasonic Signals, Systems and Technologies Lab, Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas, Madrid, Spain; Departamento de Materiales, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la Republica, 11400 Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Gamino, F., ESIME ZAC, Instituto Politécnico Nacional, México D.F., Mexico; Bazan, I., ESIME ZAC, Instituto Politécnico Nacional, México D.F., Mexico; Ramirez, A., ESIME ZAC, Instituto Politécnico Nacional, México D.F., Mexico; Ramos, A., Ultrasonic Signals, Systems and Technologies Lab, Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Científicas, Madrid, Spain; Negreira, C., Departamento de Materiales, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la Republica, 11400 Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: The spectral analysis techniques has been widely used to extract information about certain signals and the process in which those are generated. Ultrasonic (US) signal acquired from biological tissues are a particular case of that. Spectral analysis has been used to extract information from US signal related to biological tissue condition, mainly related with the internal scattering structure distribution and regularity. © 2013 IEEE.

Authors: Najson F.
Title: Remarks on the feedback interconnection of positive linear systems
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica-Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Najson, F., Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica-Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Necessary and sufficient conditions for the well-posedness and stability of a particular class of closed-loop system composed by two monotone linear systems are presented and proved in this communication. The results are here reported and proved in discrete-time as well as in continuous-time. A discussion on the relations of the aforementioned conditions with other existing stability conditions, and in particular an useful interpretation (and also alternative proofs) of these reported conditions in terms of the Nyquist Stability Theorem, is included in the paper. © 2013 AACC American Automatic Control Council.

Authors: Perez A., Romanelli A.
Title: Spatially dependent decoherence and anomalous diffussion of quantum walks
Source title: Journal of Computational and Theoretical Nanoscience
Affiliations: Departament de Física Teòrica and IFIC, Universitat de València-CSIC, Dr. Moliner 50, 46100-Burjassot, Spain; Facultad de Ingeniería, Instituto de Física, Universidad de la República, C.C. 30, C.P. 11300, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Perez, A., Departament de Física Teòrica and IFIC, Universitat de València-CSIC, Dr. Moliner 50, 46100-Burjassot, Spain; Romanelli, A., Facultad de Ingeniería, Instituto de Física, Universidad de la República, C.C. 30, C.P. 11300, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: We analyze the long time behavior of a discrete time quantum walk subject to decoherence with a strong spatial dependence, acting on one half of the lattice. We show that, except for limiting cases on the decoherence parameter, the quantum walk at late times behaves sub-ballistically, meaning that the characteristic features of the quantum walk are not completely spoiled. Contrarily to expectations, the asymptotic behavior is non Markovian, and depends on the amount of decoherence. This feature can be clearly shown on the long time value of the Generalized Chiral Distribution (GCD). Copyright © 2013 American Scientific Publishers.

Authors: Cataldo J., Durañona V., Pienika R., Pais P., Gravina A.
Title: Wind damage on citrus fruit study: Wind tunnel tests
Source title: Journal of Wind Engineering and Industrial Aerodynamics
Affiliations: Instituto de Mecánica de los Fluidos e Ingeniería Ambiental, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Departamento de Producción Vegetal, Facultad de Agronomía, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Cataldo, J., Instituto de Mecánica de los Fluidos e Ingeniería Ambiental, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Durañona, V., Instituto de Mecánica de los Fluidos e Ingeniería Ambiental, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Pienika, R., Instituto de Mecánica de los Fluidos e Ingeniería Ambiental, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Pais, P., Instituto de Mecánica de los Fluidos e Ingeniería Ambiental, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Gravina, A., Departamento de Producción Vegetal, Facultad de Agronomía, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: The interaction between citrus trees and wind was studied in a wind tunnel. Wind flows at mean velocities between 1. m/s and 3. m/s were simulated, as well as with different energy content at turbulence small-scale. The wind modeling methodologies applied to do so are presented. At a mean velocity, if the turbulence small-scales' energy is high, the consequent leaves' displacement is greater than when the former is low, decreasing the contact time between the leaf and the fruit. Nevertheless, the rest of the tree components do not present significant differences in their responses. This led us to infer that the greater energy at turbulence small-scales could be correlated with a lower period of time a leaf rubs against an adjacent fruit. Therefore, leaves' mechanical action and the consequent damage could be reduced increasing the turbulence small-scale energy content. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd.

Authors: Pessana F., Bia D., Zocalo Y., Cymberknop L., Armentano R.
Title: Time invariance mechanical arterial-wall properties: In-vitro and in-vivo studio
Source title: IFMBE Proceedings
Affiliations: Electronic Department, Buenos Aires Regional Faculty, National Technological University, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Engineering, Exact and Natural Sciences Faculty, Favaloro University, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Medicine Faculty, University of the Republic, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Pessana, F., Electronic Department, Buenos Aires Regional Faculty, National Technological University, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Engineering, Exact and Natural Sciences Faculty, Favaloro University, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Bia, D., Medicine Faculty, University of the Republic, Montevideo, Uruguay; Zocalo, Y., Medicine Faculty, University of the Republic, Montevideo, Uruguay; Cymberknop, L., Electronic Department, Buenos Aires Regional Faculty, National Technological University, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Armentano, R., Electronic Department, Buenos Aires Regional Faculty, National Technological University, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Engineering, Exact and Natural Sciences Faculty, Favaloro University, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Medicine Faculty, University of the Republic, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Arterial-wall mechanical properties (AWMP) describe structural and functional behavior in the arterial system and characterize several arterial wall diseases. Objective: The aim of this work was to assess time invariance of the AWMP in short time. Methods: using a previously developed mock circulation system, dynamic pressure-diameter tests were performed on segments of human fresh (n=10) and cryo-preserved arteries (n=7), constituting the in-vitro analysis. 20 healthy and 12 essential hypertensive men were enrolled for the in-vivo studio. An autoregressive with hexogen input adaptive digital system (ARXS) was implemented. Input and output of the ARXS in the in-vitro study were pressure (micro transducer, 1200 Hz frequency response, Königsberg Instruments Inc., Pasadena, CA, USA) and diameter (piezoelectric crystals and sonomicrometer, 1000 Hz frequency response, Triton Technology Inc., San Diego, CA, USA) respectively and in the in-vivo study pressure (pulse tonometer, Millar Instruments Inc., Houston, TX, USA) and diameter (real time B-mode ultrasound imager, ATL HDI 5000, Miami Lakes, Florida, USA) respectively. Diameter/Pressure transfer function was implemented in order to evaluate the mechanical wall properties. Short time invariance of AWMP was assessed using variation coefficients (VC). Results: both analysis (in-vivo and in- vitro) showed temporal invariance in all the wall mechanical indexes evaluated (VC <10%) when were evaluated by means of a beat to beat analysis (20 to 40 beats) respect to the single beat interpolated analysis. Conclusions: Short time invariance of the arterial wall mechanical properties could minimize the determination of mechanical wall indexes (in stable situations), using the single beat interpolation approach, reducing processing time and data analysis. © 2013 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Hernández J.A.
Title: Reduced dynamic models in epithelial transport
Source title: Journal of Biophysics
Affiliations: Sección Biofísica, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Iguá esq. Mataojo, 11400 Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Hernández, J.A., Sección Biofísica, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Iguá esq. Mataojo, 11400 Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Most models developed to represent transport across epithelia assume that the cell interior constitutes a homogeneous compartment, characterized by a single concentration value of the transported species. This conception differs significantly from the current view, in which the cellular compartment is regarded as a highly crowded media of marked structural heterogeneity. Can the finding of relatively simple dynamic properties of transport processes in epithelia be compatible with this complex structural conception of the cell interior? The purpose of this work is to contribute with one simple theoretical approach to answer this question. For this, the techniques of model reduction are utilized to obtain a two-state reduced model from more complex linear models of transcellular transport with a larger number of intermediate states. In these complex models, each state corresponds to the solute concentration in an intermediate intracellular compartment. In addition, the numerical studies reveal that it is possible to approximate a general two-state model under conditions where strict reduction of the complex models cannot be performed. These results contribute with arguments to reconcile the current conception of the cell interior as a highly complex medium with the finding of relatively simple dynamic properties of transport across epithelial cells. © 2013 Julio A. Hernández.

Title: Erratum: Growth and characterization of ZnO nanowire arrays electrodeposited into anodic alumina templates in DMSO solution (Journal of Solid State Electrochemistry (2012) 16 (197-204) (DOI 10.1007/s10008-011-1309-8) )
Source title: Journal of Solid State Electrochemistry

Authors: Brum J., Bia D., Benech N., Balay G., Armentano R., Negreira C.
Title: Medición de diámetros arteriales utilizando ultrasonido de alta resolución: Validación in vitro
Source title: IFMBE Proceedings
Affiliations: Laboratorio de Acústica Ultrasonora, Instituto de Física, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Departamento de Fisiología, Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Centro Universitario de Investigacion, Innovacion Y Diagnostico Arterial (CUiiDARTE), Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay

Abstract: In this work a new method, based in ultrasonography, to quantify arterial diameter is discussed and compared with the gold standart method: sonomicrometry. The results indicated that the new method ensure an optimal diameter quantification. © 2013 Springer.

Authors: Riveros G., Ramírez D., Dalchiele E.A., Marotti R., Peter L.M., Grez P., Martín F., Ramos-Barrado J.R.
Title: Electrodeposition and characterization of hematite films obtained from DMSO solution
Source title: ECS Transactions
