Química, Universidad de Málaga, E29071 Málaga, Spain; Ramos-Barrado, J.R., Laboratorio de Materiales y Superficies (Unidad Asociada Al CSIC), Departamento de Física Aplicada and Ing. Química, Universidad de Málaga, E29071 Málaga, Spain
Abstract: The present study shows the results obtained in the electrodeposition of hematite thin films from DMSO solution employing FeCl3 and molecular oxygen as precursors. The films were obtained through a potential cycling program at different cathodic limits and at different electrolytic bath temperatures. In all cases, as-grown films were amorphous and photoelectrochemically inactive. An annealing procedure is necessary to completely transform the electrodeposited iron oxide to α-Fe 2O3 phase. XRD analyses confirm the presence of diffraction peaks corresponding to hematite after annealing, showing a strong preferential orientation of the [110] axis vertical to the substrate. Different techniques (XRD techniques, XPS analyses, SEM images, UV-Vis spectroscopy, Mott-Schottky plots and photocurrent-potential curves) have been employed in order to characterize the films and determinate their properties according with the conditions of electrodeposition and the annealing temperature. © The Electrochemical Society.

Authors: Herrera E.O., Val L.
Title: Extending LR parsing to implement rewriting semantics in extensible programming languages
Source title: Lecture Notes in Electrical Engineering
Affiliations: Departamento de Informática Y Ciencias de la Computación, Universidad Católica del Uruguay - UCUDAL, 8 de octubre 2738, 11600 Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Herrera, E.O., Departamento de Informática Y Ciencias de la Computación, Universidad Católica del Uruguay - UCUDAL, 8 de octubre 2738, 11600 Montevideo, Uruguay; Val, L., Departamento de Informática Y Ciencias de la Computación, Universidad Católica del Uruguay - UCUDAL, 8 de octubre 2738, 11600 Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Extensible programming is a software development technique where the programming language allows the developers to add new syntactic constructs. Consequently, developers can use this technique to enrich their programming language with new syntax specifically tailored to the problem domain in which they are working. However, the creation of an extensible programming language poses a series of implementation challenges and requires the use of specialized parsing algorithms. Although much discussion has taken place, there exists little information on precisely how extensible programming can be implemented, especially using LR parsing. This chapter presents a complete and operational set of implementation steps and the precise alterations to the LR parsing algorithm that are needed in order to create an extensible programming language. © 2013 Springer Science+Business Media.

Authors: Benavente I., Miguez M.
Title: A HV pulse generator for PEF applications
Source title: EAMTA 2013 - Proceedings of the Argentine School of Micro-Nanoelectronics, Technology and Applications 2013
Affiliations: Laboratorio Tecnológico del Uruguay (LATU), Universidad Católica del Uruguay (UCU), Uruguay; Departamento de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Universidad Católica del Uruguay (UCU), Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Benavente, I., Laboratorio Tecnológico del Uruguay (LATU), Universidad Católica del Uruguay (UCU), Uruguay; Miguez, M., Departamento de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Universidad Católica del Uruguay (UCU), Uruguay
Abstract: In this work, a high voltage (HV) pulse generator for pulsed electric fields (PEF) application in treatment of liquid food is presented. A complete overview of the target application is followed by a detailed analysis and design of a 10 stages Marx generator. The pulse generator uses semiconductor switches to generate up to 30kV pulses of 2μs and 2400Hz frequency. Simulation of the electrical characteristics of the pulse generator and of the electric field, and temperature variations inside the chamber are presented as well as measured results of a 3-stage prototype.

Authors: Puyol R., Lenzi G., Barg G., Arnaud A.
Title: A portable, high density EEG acquisition system
Source title: EAMTA 2013 - Proceedings of the Argentine School of Micro-Nanoelectronics, Technology and Applications 2013
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Puyol, R., Electrical Engineering Department, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay; Lenzi, G., Electrical Engineering Department, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay; Barg, G., Electrical Engineering Department, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay; Arnaud, A., Electrical Engineering Department, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: The search for simple yet precise electroencephalogram (EEG) recording systems has been long desired by researchers in the psychophysiology field. During the last two decades, the advancement of instrumentation amplifiers and microcontrollers has provided the adequate tools for the task. In this paper the design of a portable embedded system capable of recording up to 128 EEG electrodes simultaneously is presented. EEG records are stored in a standard SD flash card and can be transmitted to a host PC with a Bluetooth module. The main features of this device are portability, low power consumption, scalability, and low noise among others. The implemented device may allow psychophysiology researchers to perform non-invasive experiments, where individuals are not tied with an uncomfortable group of cables to amplifiers and test equipment.

Authors: Soler-Guitart J., Bladé E., Bofill-Abelló J., Gamazo P.
Title: "Raster approach" to the hydrodynamic problem of 2D free surface flow ["enfoque ráster" del problema hidrodinámico del flujo en lámina libre en 2D]
Source title: Tecnologia y Ciencias del Agua
Affiliations: Control, Dynamics and Aplications. CoDAlab, Departamento de Matemática Aplicada III, Universidad Politécnica de Catalunya, c/Compte d'Urgell, 187, 08036 Barcelona, Spain; Instituto Mixto de Investigación FLUMEN, Departamento de Ingeniería Hidráulica, Marítima y Ambiental, Universidad Politécnica de Catalunya, c/Jordi Girona, 1-3, 08034 Barcelona, Spain; Cátedra de Software Libre, Universidad Politécnica de Catalunya, Avenida de les Bases de Manresa, 61-73, 08240 Manresa, Spain; Ingeniero Civil, Doctor en Hidrología Subterránea, Departamento Del Agua, Regional Norte, Universidad de la República, Gral. Rivera 1350, 50000 Salto, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Soler-Guitart, J., Control, Dynamics and Aplications. CoDAlab, Departamento de Matemática Aplicada III, Universidad Politécnica de Catalunya, c/Compte d'Urgell, 187, 08036 Barcelona, Spain; Bladé, E., Instituto Mixto de Investigación FLUMEN, Departamento de Ingeniería Hidráulica, Marítima y Ambiental, Universidad Politécnica de Catalunya, c/Jordi Girona, 1-3, 08034 Barcelona, Spain; Bofill-Abelló, J., Cátedra de Software Libre, Universidad Politécnica de Catalunya, Avenida de les Bases de Manresa, 61-73, 08240 Manresa, Spain; Gamazo, P., Ingeniero Civil, Doctor en Hidrología Subterránea, Departamento Del Agua, Regional Norte, Universidad de la República, Gral. Rivera 1350, 50000 Salto, Uruguay
Abstract: Geographical information systems traditionally provide information using two formats-raster and vector. Each one of these formats is handled according to their independent algorithms. Consequently, any type of hydraulic study performed in a territory contains information that can be classified by these two formats. LiDAR is the most precise technology used to generate Digital Elevation Models (DEM) for large areas, with a spatial resolution of 1 to 2 m and a minimum precision in height. It gives the cartographic information its raster characteristic, with the cell as its basic unit of information. Consequently, this kind of information is very suitable to the generation of structured quadrilateral meshes to numerically model free surface flow in two dimensions. The main objective of this work was to present an adaptation of the classic explicit first order finite volumes scheme to a finite square volumes (FSV) mesh which, directly and without interpolations, makes each cell in the DEM (or raster) equal to the corresponding FSV. Consequently, the dimensions of the FSV are those of the base DEM cell. This is presented herein as a raster approach to the hydrodynamic problem of free surface flow in two dimensions. With the raster approach, the database for the mesh topology does not need to be consulted for each instant of time and, therefore, the efficiency of the numeric process is greatly improved. Consequently, larger-sized problems can be addressed. An additional objective was to compare both approaches by solving an illustrative example.

Authors: Pérez Barthaburu M., Aguiar I., Bañobre C., Galain I., Cárdenas A., Mombrú M., Noguera A., Bentos Pereira H., Rodríguez Chialanza M., Fornaro L.
Title: Approaching materials science and solar energy to Uruguayan school children
Source title: Materials Research Society Symposium Proceedings
Affiliations: Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, CURE, Universidad de la República, Rocha, Uruguay; Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Pérez Barthaburu, M., Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, CURE, Universidad de la República, Rocha, Uruguay; Aguiar, I., Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Bañobre, C., Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, CURE, Universidad de la República, Rocha, Uruguay; Galain, I., Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Cárdenas, A., Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Mombrú, M., Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Noguera, A., Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, CURE, Universidad de la República, Rocha, Uruguay; Bentos Pereira, H., Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, CURE, Universidad de la República, Rocha, Uruguay; Rodríguez Chialanza, M., Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Fornaro, L., Grupo de Semiconductores Compuestos, CURE, Universidad de la República, Rocha, Uruguay
Abstract: There is an extended concern related to renewable energies in South America. Particularly the Uruguayan government is encouraging initiatives in solar, biofuels and eolic wind energy issues. On the other hand, and in a similar manner than in other countries, Uruguay celebrates the "Science and Technology Week", an activity annually organized, focused on sharing knowledge between scientists and technologists and society. In 2012, this week was devoted to energy and sustainability. In this framework we carried out an interactive activity in five primary school classes with the aim of bringing materials science and solar energy to children between 10 and 12 years old. In the beginning of the activity we asked students to complete a brief survey containing a few questions about materials and energy. This survey allowed us to further the children's knowledge about these topics. Then, we introduced materials science history relating it with mankind development. From the active participation of children in the activity, we derived to materials applied in solar cells, performing demonstrations with real solar cells and showing their importance for improving our country energetic efficiency while preserving the environment. At the end of each activity students showed great enthusiasm about including alternative energies in their daily life. Furthermore, they realized the importance of materials science, and were capable of understanding the relation between materials and the development of solar cells. We consider the spread of this activity as an excellent way of creating consciousness from an early age, which will help in the achievement of a more sustainable country. © 2013 Materials Research Society.

Authors: Larrambebere G.
Title: Summer Theatre
Source title: Construction and Building Materials
Affiliations: Dieste y Montañez, Carlos Roxlo 1606, P.C., 11200 Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Larrambebere, G., Dieste y Montañez, Carlos Roxlo 1606, P.C., 11200 Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Montevideo, the capital city of Uruguay, has an open air Summer Theatre located at a public garden, Parque Rodó, close to the shore of Río de la Plata river. The authorities of the City of Montevideo decided to replace the 45 years old metallic acoustic shell by a new shell of reinforced brick and requested our office to project a shell of about 600 m 2 , which should cover the stage of the theatre and should fit the existing colourful open tribune. It was designed as a conoidal vault of reinforced brick. In addition to self weight, wind pressure and other stresses, the vault should be able to bear hanging devices for illumination, acoustics, curtains, etc., totaling 72 tons. The ruled surfaced was generated by the movement of a straight line along two catenary arches. A finite element program was used for designing, which dealt with curves with different degrees of approximation to catenaries. A special formwork was projected, consisting of nine rows of steel towers that supported a wood and timber superstructure. Modular steel towers were designed to be reused in following works. The masonry consisted of hollow bricks (25 cm × 25 cm × 17 cm), manufactured in Montevideo. Steel bars were placed in the 2 cm thick joints between bricks and in the external mortar layer. In order to increase steel protection against corrosion, the mortar for the joints and for the external layer was designed with low water/cement ratio. Laying out the curved surface and positioning the joints on the formwork presented considerable difficulties. Organisation of labour force in two shifts with complementary tasks brought economical and time benefits. The project was prepared in 2006. The construction took 4 months, it finished in December 2006. This paper presents the process of design and construction of the shell. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd.

Authors: Robledo F., Romero P., Sartor P.
Title: A novel Interpolation technique to address the Edge-Reliability Problem
Source title: International Congress on Ultra Modern Telecommunications and Control Systems and Workshops
Affiliations: Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Julio Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, 11300, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Robledo, F., Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Julio Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, 11300, Uruguay; Romero, P., Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Julio Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, 11300, Uruguay; Sartor, P., Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Julio Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, 11300, Uruguay
Abstract: In this paper we deal with the Edge-Reliability Problem: given a connected simple graph G = (V, E) with perfect nodes and links failing independently with equal probability 1-p, find the probability RG(p) that the network remains connected. The edge reliability RG(p) is a polynomial in p with degree m = |E|, and the exact computation of RG(p) is in the class of NP-Hard problems. However, the related literature is vast, and offers bounds and estimation techniques, as well as exponential algorithms to exactly find that polynomial. We propose a novel interpolation-based technique that exploits the structure of the Hilbert space L2[0; 1], and combines the efficiency of Newton interpolation with the simplicity of Monte Carlo reliability estimation in selected abscissas in [0; 1]. The aim is to guide the polynomial search respecting algebraic properties of the target polynomial coefficients. We illustrate the effectiveness of the algorithm in the lights of a naive graph with limited size, and discuss several hints for future work. © 2013 IEEE.

Authors: Napolitano F., Soldati A., Geck J., Suescun L., Acuña L., Fernandez Zuvich A., Lamas D.G., Serquis A.
Title: Characterization of (La,Sr)(Ti,Co)O3 oxides for symmetrical solid oxide fuel cell electrodes
Source title: ECS Transactions
Affiliations: CONICET, Centro Atómico Bariloche, S. C. de Bariloche (R8402AGP), Argentina; Leibniz Institute for Solid State and Materials Research IFW Dresden, Dresden, Germany; Cryssmat-Lab., Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; CINSO, Centro de Investigaciones en Sólidos, CITEDEF-CONICET, Villa Martelli, Argentina; Laboratorio de Caracterización de Materiales, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad Nacional Del Comahue, Neuquén, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Napolitano, F., CONICET, Centro Atómico Bariloche, S. C. de Bariloche (R8402AGP), Argentina; Soldati, A., CONICET, Centro Atómico Bariloche, S. C. de Bariloche (R8402AGP), Argentina; Geck, J., Leibniz Institute for Solid State and Materials Research IFW Dresden, Dresden, Germany; Suescun, L., Cryssmat-Lab., Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Acuña, L., CINSO, Centro de Investigaciones en Sólidos, CITEDEF-CONICET, Villa Martelli, Argentina; Fernandez Zuvich, A., CONICET, Centro Atómico Bariloche, S. C. de Bariloche (R8402AGP), Argentina; Lamas, D.G., Laboratorio de Caracterización de Materiales, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad Nacional Del Comahue, Neuquén, Argentina; Serquis, A., CONICET, Centro Atómico Bariloche, S. C. de Bariloche (R8402AGP), Argentina
Abstract: In this work, a combined synchrotron X-ray diffraction (XPD), Xray absorption near edge spectroscopy (XANES) and Extended Xray Absorption Fine Structure (EXAFS) study of La0.4Sr0.6Ti 1-yCoyO3±δ (0 ≤ y ≤ 0.5), intended as symmetric solid oxide fuel cells electrode, is presented. Charge compensation mechanisms were characterized by room temperature measurements; LSTC has a perovskite pseudocubic structure with an A-site vacancy concentration related with Co doping level. This result seems to be triggered by the fact that Ti remains in a higher formal valence (around 4+) independent of the Co concentrations. On the contrary, Co K-edge XANES spectra show a dependency with the doping level but this seems to be related to structural changes. In-situ measurements simulating a symmetric SOFC working environment show that LSTC undergoes a rhombohedral to cubic perovskite phase transition with critical temperature dependent of the structural distortion level. © The Electrochemical Society.

Authors: De Valcarcel G.J., Di Franco C., Hinarejos M., Perez A., Roldan E., Romanelli A., Silva F.
Title: Multidimensional quantum walks: Diabolical points, optical wave-like propagation, and multipartite entanglement
Source title: 2013 Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics Europe and International Quantum Electronics Conference, CLEO/Europe-IQEC 2013
Affiliations: Departament d'Òptica, Universitat de València, Dr. Moliner 50, 46100-Burjassot, Spain; Departament de Física Teòrica and IFIC, Universitat de València, CSIC, Dr. Moliner 50, 46100-Burjassot, Spain; Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, C.C. 30, C.P. 11000, Montevideo, Uruguay; Centre for Theoretical, Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics, Queen's University, Belfast, BT7 1NN, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: De Valcarcel, G.J., Departament d'Òptica, Universitat de València, Dr. Moliner 50, 46100-Burjassot, Spain; Di Franco, C., Centre for Theoretical, Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics, Queen's University, Belfast, BT7 1NN, United Kingdom; Hinarejos, M., Departament de Física Teòrica and IFIC, Universitat de València, CSIC, Dr. Moliner 50, 46100-Burjassot, Spain; Perez, A., Departament de Física Teòrica and IFIC, Universitat de València, CSIC, Dr. Moliner 50, 46100-Burjassot, Spain; Roldan, E., Departament d'Òptica, Universitat de València, Dr. Moliner 50, 46100-Burjassot, Spain; Romanelli, A., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, C.C. 30, C.P. 11000, Montevideo, Uruguay; Silva, F., Departament d'Òptica, Universitat de València, Dr. Moliner 50, 46100-Burjassot, Spain
Abstract: Quantum walks (QWs) are important for quantum information science, but are becoming also interesting for other fields of research as this simple quantum diffusion model finds analogues in diverse physical systems, optical ones in particular. The experimental capabilities regarding QWs have remarkably increased along recent years and several aspects of QWs are now open to experimental research, multidimensional QWs in particular [1]. © 2013 IEEE.

Authors: De Los Santos-Gregoraschuk J., Hernández-García G.
Title: Numerical modeling of an aquifer in two representations schematically: Raigon, Uruguay [Modelación numérica de un acuífero mediante dos esquemas representativos: Raigón, Uruguay]
Source title: Tecnologia y Ciencias del Agua
Affiliations: Instituto de Mecánica de Los Fluidos e Ingeniería Ambiental (IMFIA), Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Julio Herrera y Reissig 565, 11300 Montevideo, Uruguay; Instituto de Geofísica, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Circuito Interior, Ciudad Universitaria, 04360 México, D.F., Mexico
Authors with affiliations: De Los Santos-Gregoraschuk, J., Instituto de Mecánica de Los Fluidos e Ingeniería Ambiental (IMFIA), Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Julio Herrera y Reissig 565, 11300 Montevideo, Uruguay; Hernández-García, G., Instituto de Geofísica, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Circuito Interior, Ciudad Universitaria, 04360 México, D.F., Mexico
Abstract: The Raigon Aquifer System (RAS) contains fluvial sediments and has both free and confined sectors. Located in southern Uruguay, its area measures 1800 km2 and its demand is high. It has been the subject of several studies since 1990, and the first digital model to represent it was developed in 1999. This model divided the region into four independent sectors with constant head boundary conditions. The results presented herein compare two portions of the study area and show changes in boundary conditions to a steady-state. The first model was based on constant head boundaries while the boundaries for the second - now internal singularities - were represented by rivers interconnected with the aquifer system. The results show great similarity in the behavior of water levels, with similar distributions for recharge areas and hydraulic conductivity-critical parameters for the fit between the observed and calculated values of the decision variable.

Authors: Costa D., Miguez M., Arnaud A.
Title: A safe circuit for the measurement of stimuli pulse amplitude in biomedical devices
Source title: EAMTA 2013 - Proceedings of the Argentine School of Micro-Nanoelectronics, Technology and Applications 2013
Affiliations: Departamento de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Costa, D., Departamento de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Uruguay; Miguez, M., Departamento de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Uruguay; Arnaud, A., Departamento de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Uruguay
Abstract: In this paper an integrating amplifier aimed at estimating pulse amplitude in implantable stimuli delivery devices is presented. The proposed circuit can integrate during each stimulus the effective voltage being applied to tissue, to later use this measure in a self-calibration procedure or in a closed loop stimulator scheme. The circuit was designed and simulated using a 0.6μm HV CMOS technology, it consumes only 8μA current from the battery when it is turned on, and shows an error below 3% for pulses ranging from 100μs to 5ms, and from 350mV to 15V if the time-voltage product does not saturate the integrating capacitor. The circuit is safe in the sense it is not harmful for the patient in the case of a single (independent) circuit failure. The focus of this work is in a pacemaker application, but the developed circuit block can be incorporated in a wide set of biomedical devices.

Authors: Alonsoperez M.V., Ali Nasseri S., Somalwar U.
Title: Improving communication for space exploration missions to mars
Source title: Proceedings of the International Astronautical Congress, IAC
Affiliations: IEETech, Uruguay; Institute for Aerospace Studies, University of Toronto, Canada; Australian Aerospace, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Alonsoperez, M.V., IEETech, Uruguay; Ali Nasseri, S., Institute for Aerospace Studies, University of Toronto, Canada; Somalwar, U., Australian Aerospace, Australia
Abstract: Currently, space agencies around the globe are focusing their exploration programs on the Moon, Near-Earth Objects (NEOs, such as asteroids) and Mars. However, one of the main difficulties in attempting such journeys lies in maintaining communications with the distant spacecraft. Communication systems are indispensable in enabling space exploration by providing a means of navigating and controlling the spacecraft. They are also essential for downloading data from scientific instruments. The issue of communication for space exploration was addressed by the 2012 Space Generation Congress (SGC) Exploration Working Group composed of 25 students and young professionals of the space industry with variety of backgrounds from 16 different countries. The main objective of the 2012 SGC Exploration Working Group was to analyze the current situation in space communications and to draw recommendations for improving existing capabilities, as well as future systems. After analyzing the different issues with communication in the space exploration context and the different destinations for space explorations missions, the working group chose to focus on providing solutions to improve communication for Mars exploration missions. This paper outlines the findings and recommendations by the Working Group which focus on improving both regulatory and technological aspects of space communication and highlight the importance of international collaboration in solving these issues. Copyright© (2013) by the International Astronautical Federation.

Authors: Zorrilla J.M.
Title: Calibration of an intelligent concrete wharf to seismic and berthing loads
Source title: fib Symposium TEL-AVIV 2013: Engineering a Concrete Future: Technology, Modeling and Construction, Proceedings
Affiliations: Constructora Santa Maria, A.A.H.E.S.-Fib, A.C.I., Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Zorrilla, J.M., Constructora Santa Maria, A.A.H.E.S.-Fib, A.C.I., Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: In 2002 it was found that Fluid Yiscous Dampers, a Star Wars technology device, could add a no linear viscous dissipation term in the partial differential equations defined by the mechanics of a concrete wharf founded on vertical piles. This term modified the dynamical efforts at berthing on the wharf structure, resulting in up to four times lower efforts on the pi les and on the concrete slab. The first wharf structure with FVDs, Terminal Ontur Wharf, an Intelligent Structure, was nominated to the 2010 fib (International Concrete Federation) Awards for Outstanding Structures "in recognition of its positive contribution to the reputation and promotion of concrete structures". The wharf is a high-performance precast concrete structure, founded in vertical precast concrete piles driven to refusal into the river bottom. This paper describes the method used to calibrate the Fluid Yiscous Dampers in order to optimize the wharf structure resistance to live and berth loads.

Authors: Farro I., Bia D., Zocalo Y., Torrado J., Farro F., Florio L., Lluberas R., Armentano R.L.
Title: Aging-related changes and reference values for the carotid intima-media thickness in a Uruguayan population
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society, EMBS
Affiliations: Physiology Department, Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Cardiology Department, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Favaloro University, Buenos Aires, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Farro, I., Physiology Department, Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Bia, D., Physiology Department, Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Zocalo, Y., Physiology Department, Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Torrado, J., Physiology Department, Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Farro, F., Physiology Department, Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Florio, L., Cardiology Department, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Lluberas, R., Cardiology Department, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Armentano, R.L., Physiology Department, Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay, Favaloro University, Buenos Aires, Argentina
Abstract: Carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT) is a well-established subclinical marker of atherosclerosis. Non-invasive vascular evaluation has emerged as a useful tool to aid in individual cardiovascular (CV) risk stratification and diagnose. The use of CIMT in CV risk stratification requires knowing the expected reference values for the population studied. Our aim were: a) to evaluate the relationship between aging and CIMT, b) to analyze gender and side (right vs left) related-differences in CIMT and c) to determine the CIMT reference values for an Uruguayan population taking into account aging-related CIMT changes. Methods: 367 asymptomatic subjects without known CV disease or risk factors were included in the study. Subjects were divided into six age groups. High-resolution B-mode ultrasound images of both (right and left) common carotid arteries were obtained based on the techniques and recommendations described in international consensus. Results: No significant age-related differences in CIMT between men and women were observed. The mean left CIMT was thicker compared with right CIMT in groups 4, 5 and 6. However, there were no significant differences in those groups. The nomogram model was constructed from data base, in which the 95% confidence interval was considered. Diagnosis thresholds were determined as well. Conclusion: We define reference values of CIMT for our population using gold standard techniques which contributes to standard techniques which contributes to an improved insight into clinical practice and can be used routinely for evaluation. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Chiancone A., Larrechea E.M.
Title: Innovations in the private sector in Uruguay: Nanotechnology in cosmetics
Source title: Nanotechnology Law and Business
Affiliations: Universidad de la República, SNI-ANII, RELANS, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Chiancone, A., Universidad de la República, SNI-ANII, RELANS, Uruguay; Larrechea, E.M., Universidad de la República, SNI-ANII, RELANS, Uruguay
Abstract: The objective of this article is to examine how and in what ways the Uruguayan business sector, generally not very innovative, is supporting innovation in nanotechnology. The article also identi-fies the main local enterprise innovation challenges in this new field. To that end, the article ana-lyzes the case of the application of nanotechnology to a line of cosmetics produced in Uruguay, made with the medicinal plant marcela (Achyrocline satureioides). This line of cosmetic products was recently launched into the local market, the result of an alliance between academic actors and the productive-private sector, and promoted by a public agency. In Uruguay, where the develop-ment of nanotechnology is relatively recent, researchers and institutions work toward the creation of local capacities and resources.

Authors: Vrolijk A., Bergmann M., Alonsoperez M.V., Morris T.
Title: The guidebook on small satellite programs: Management of an international team, lessons learned, and future visions
Source title: Proceedings of the International Astronautical Congress, IAC
Affiliations: Canadian Space Society, Toronto, ON, Canada; Institute of Communication Networks and Satellite Communications, Graz University of Technology, Graz, Austria; Space Generation Advisory Council, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Vrolijk, A., Canadian Space Society, Toronto, ON, Canada; Bergmann, M., Institute of Communication Networks and Satellite Communications, Graz University of Technology, Graz, Austria; Alonsoperez, M.V., Space Generation Advisory Council, Montevideo, Uruguay; Morris, T.
Abstract: Small Satellite Programs have been a common way for countries, academia, industries, and non-profit organizations to start a space program. Thus, based on data and experience from historical small satellite missions, expert knowledge in the field, and available literature, a team of 39 participants of the 2011 Space Studies Program of the International Space University (ISU) compiled a guidebook on small satellite programs aiming to support newcomers with their first steps. In this paper we describe the motivation, development, and main topics of this guidebook. We detail how a group of 39 people from 24 countries were coordinated and focused on a common goal within a short period of time, what difficulties arose and how these were tackled. Furthermore, we briefly answer the major questions addressed in the guidebook: Why small satellite programs? What can be accomplished? Who is involved? What legal and regulatory issues exist? How is the program concept envisioned? How is the mission concept implemented?.

Authors: Piccion A., Milicua S., Lopez M.N., Camacho M.
Title: Adaptive thermal comfort studies in public buildings, Uruguay case of moderate climate
Source title: Proceedings - 28th International PLEA Conference on Sustainable Architecture + Urban Design: Opportunities, Limits and Needs - Towards an Environmentally Responsible Architecture, PLEA 2012
Affiliations: Facultad de Arquitectura, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Piccion, A., Facultad de Arquitectura, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Milicua, S., Facultad de Arquitectura, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Lopez, M.N., Facultad de Arquitectura, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Camacho, M., Facultad de Arquitectura, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Abstract: In Uruguay since 2005, the government has implemented a Program of Energetic Efficiency focused on improving the use of energy for the final users of all economic sectors. For this purpose, the thermal comfort in public buildings has been studied in order to set a range of comfort temperatures according to the type of building and moderate climate conditions. The article proposes an approach of thermal comfort in public buildings with variable occupation. Four buildings have been studied in two cities: Two with artificially conditioning environments and two under free running conditions, as well as occupants' responses about ambient temperature conditions, preferences and actions to achieve comfort, through surveys. The environmental data is linked with the response of people based on adaptive thermal comfort. Two different range of comfort temperature are settled for each city. The annual ranges proposed for Montevideo (18.8 to 27.2°C) and Salto (19.2 to 28.1°C) have an amplitude of at least 7°C while for ASHRAE the range is 19 to 25°C. The operative temperature presents meaningful correlations with the response of "neither cold nor hot" in naturally conditioned buildings so this could be used as an index of thermal satisfaction in this kind of buildings.

Authors: Gaviraghi G., Miller J.D., Marzocca P.
Title: Instant starship: A reference plan for a manned interstellar mission
Source title: Proceedings of the International Astronautical Congress, IAC
Affiliations: Exponential Design Lab, Montevideo, Uruguay; University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, 90033, United States; Clarkson University, Potsdam, NY, 13699, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gaviraghi, G., Exponential Design Lab, Montevideo, Uruguay; Miller, J.D., University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA, 90033, United States; Marzocca, P., Clarkson University, Potsdam, NY, 13699, United States
Abstract: Instant Starship is a reference plan for a manned interstellar mission, born in the wake of the 100YSS, sponsored by DARPA and NASA. This plan consists of a full conceptual design that considers most of the requirements for a manned interstellar mission, including systems and subsystems, strategies, and motivation. For resource utilization, safety considerations, and immediate start of activities, a captured asteroid engineered as a space settlement is considered. Copyright © (2012) by the International Astronautical Federation.

Authors: Igounet P., Dufrechou E., Pedemonte M., Ezzatti P.
Title: A study on mixed precision techniques for a GPU-based SIP solver
Source title: Proceedings - 3rd Workshop on Applications for Multi-Core Architecture, WAMCA 2012
Affiliations: Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Igounet, P., Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Dufrechou, E., Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Pedemonte, M., Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Ezzatti, P., Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: This article presents the study and application of mixed precision techniques to accelerate a GPU-based implementation of the Strongly Implicit Procedure (SIP) to solve hepta-diagonal linear systems. In particular, two different options to incorporate mixed precision in the GPU implementation are discussed and one of them is implemented. The experimental evaluation of our proposal demonstrates that a runtime similar to a single precision implementation on GPU can be attained, but achieving a numerical accuracy comparable to double precision arithmetic. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Osborne J.R., Victoria M., Lanza A., Desclaux D.F., Goswami N., Ventura D., Alonso G., Moser M., Grote V., Garcia-Cuadrado G., Pérez-Poch A.
Title: Effect of mental arithmetic on cardiovascular responses during parabolic flights: The barcelona zero-G challenge
Source title: Proceedings of the International Astronautical Congress, IAC
Affiliations: International Space University (ISU), France; Space Generation Advisory Council (SGAC), Uruguay; Zero2infinity, Spain; Institute of Physiology, Medical University Graz, Harrachgasse 21, A-8010 Graz, Austria; Aeroclub Barcelona-Sabadell, Spain; Medical University of Graz, Austria; Human Research Institute, Weiz, Austria; Aerospace Cluster of Catalonia, BAIE, Spain; Universitat Politecnica de Catalunya (UPC), Spain
Authors with affiliations: Osborne, J.R., International Space University (ISU), France; Victoria, M., Space Generation Advisory Council (SGAC), Uruguay; Lanza, A., Space Generation Advisory Council (SGAC), Uruguay; Desclaux, D.F., Zero2infinity, Spain; Goswami, N., Institute of Physiology, Medical University Graz, Harrachgasse 21, A-8010 Graz, Austria; Ventura, D., Aeroclub Barcelona-Sabadell, Spain; Alonso, G., Aeroclub Barcelona-Sabadell, Spain; Moser, M., Medical University of Graz, Austria, Human Research Institute, Weiz, Austria; Grote, V., Medical University of Graz, Austria, Human Research Institute, Weiz, Austria; Garcia-Cuadrado, G., Aerospace Cluster of Catalonia, BAIE, Spain; Pérez-Poch, A., Universitat Politecnica de Catalunya (UPC), Spain
Abstract: When an astronaut transitions from a low to high gravitational environment, fluid shifts from the head towards the feet results in orthostatic intolerance, leading to syncope. Ground based experiments have shown that by stimulating the cardiovascular system via simple mental stressors, syncope can be delayed, potentially enabling astronauts to reach assistance before loss of consciousness. However, the effect of mental stressors on the stimulation of the cardiovascular system is unknown in gravitational environments different than that of Earth's. As such, this paper investigates the effects that mental stressors have under various gravitational environments. To do this, a pilot study was performed in which two participants were own on two separate parabolic flights that simulated hyper and hypogravity conditions. The plane used was an Aerobatic Single-Engine Cap-1 OB plane (twin seater), and each participant executed 11 parabolas. The participants were the winners of the Barcelona Zero-G Challenge 2011 organized by UPC Barcelona Tech and Aeroclub Barcelona-Sabadell. Measurements were made of the participants' hemodynamic and autonomic response throughout the parabolas, using a Chronocord. Comparisons of the baseline response without mental stressors, and the response with mental stressors were made. It was determined that there is an increase in cardiovascular activity during hypo- and hyper-gravity when performing mental arithmetic. ©(2012) by the International Astronautieal Federation.

Authors: Flores J.L., Ferrari J.A., Fernández A., Alonso J.R., Ayubi G.A., Matías Di Martino J.
Title: Methods for edge enhancement in color images based on derivative operations
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Electronic Department, University of Guadalajara, Av. Revolución #1500, CP. 44430, Guadalajara, Jal., Mexico; Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería (UdelaR), J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Flores, J.L., Electronic Department, University of Guadalajara, Av. Revolución #1500, CP. 44430, Guadalajara, Jal., Mexico; Ferrari, J.A., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería (UdelaR), J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay; Fernández, A., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería (UdelaR), J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay; Alonso, J.R., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería (UdelaR), J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay; Ayubi, G.A., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería (UdelaR), J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay; Matías Di Martino, J., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería (UdelaR), J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: We present optical methods for edge enhancement in color images using optical derivative operations (first order derivative and Laplacian operator). The proposed methods is based on the polarization properties of liquid-crystal displays (LCD) and on the capacity of digital micro mirror devices to generate a (positive) copy of the digital image used as input, and simultaneously a complementary color replica of it. In the proposed optical setup the negative and positive replicas are at the same time imagined across a plane. First we analyzed the case when the negative replica has a lateral differential displacement relative to the original one; an image with enhanced first derivatives along a specific direction is obtained. In the case when the negative replica is low-pass filtered, one obtains the Laplacian of the original image. Unlike Fourier, our proposal works with incoherent illumination and does not require precise alignment, and thus, it could be a useful tool for edge extraction/enhancement in large images in real-time applications. Validation experiments are presented. © 2012 SPIE.

Authors: Cornalino E., Gutierrez A., Cases G., Draper M., Chaer R.
Title: A valorization of the short-term forecasting of wind power
Source title: Proceedings of the 2012 6th IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution: Latin America Conference and Exposition, T and D-LA 2012
Affiliations: UTE, Uruguay; Institute of Fluid Mechanics and Environmental Engineering, Uruguay; Academic College of Engineering, Uruguay; Institute of Fluid Mechanics, University of the Republic, Uruguay; Institute of Electrical Engineering, Uruguay; Uruguay IEEE-PES and IM Chapter, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Cornalino, E., UTE, Uruguay; Gutierrez, A., Institute of Fluid Mechanics and Environmental Engineering, Uruguay, Academic College of Engineering, Uruguay; Cases, G., Institute of Fluid Mechanics, University of the Republic, Uruguay; Draper, M., UTE, Uruguay; Chaer, R., UTE, Uruguay, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Uruguay, Uruguay IEEE-PES and IM Chapter, Uruguay
Abstract: This paper presents an estimate of the value of information of the hourly wind forecast of the next three days when the forecast is used in the programming task of the operation of the generation system. The value of information is measured as the expected future operating costs without having the forecast minus the expected future operating cost when having it. The paper presents a calculation methodology and its application to the Uruguay in 2015. The result shows that such information has a value of around 1% of Cost of Supply Demand (CSD). © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Thomasset P.J.
Title: Field pole spares bid for tenders specification guide for salient pole hydro generators
Source title: Proceedings of the 2012 6th IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution: Latin America Conference and Exposition, T and D-LA 2012
Affiliations: Gabriel Terra Hydro Power Plant, Rincón del Bonete, Paso de los Toros, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Thomasset, P.J., Gabriel Terra Hydro Power Plant, Rincón del Bonete, Paso de los Toros, Uruguay
Abstract: Every time stator winding maintenance is to be done, hydro generator field poles are parts that are taken out/in on the rotor rim, being a high risk operation, as the field pole are a fragile piece of the generator, risking a pole damage. Repair a damaged field pole can take take months if the damage is a mayor one, and has to be done overseas at foreign contractor workshops, so to have spare parts pole pieces ready to fit in the rotor rim is a must. Currently there are no standard guide or papers support for writing a bid for tenders to buy new spares field poles. This papers as a guide, joins what was gotten in periodical papers, standards and manufactures brochures, to have material specification for hydro generators field poles, assuring a minimal quality for the tenders of the bid process. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Berrutti F., Giusto Á., Artenstein M.
Title: Dynamic characterization of wind farms and their impact in power systems oscillations
Source title: Proceedings of the 2012 6th IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution: Latin America Conference and Exposition, T and D-LA 2012
Affiliations: Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Berrutti, F., Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Giusto, Á., Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Artenstein, M., Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Abstract: This paper has two main objectives: to explain the dynamic characterization of wind farms as part of their integration in power systems using modal analysis and to present a qualitative development for understanding the main factors that impact on the damping of the oscillation modes by incorporating wind farms based on variable speed wind turbines. Moreover, such developments are validated by performing simulations on a 2017 peak scenario for the Uruguayan electrical system, showing a strong interaction between the hydroelectrics power plants located on the Río Negro and future wind farms Palmatir and Agua Leguas. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Larrosa D., Coppes E., Casaravilla G., Chaer R.
Title: Differences between the operations of the generation power system of Uruguay operated minimizing the expected value vs. minimizing the value at risk of the future operating costs
Source title: Proceedings of the 2012 6th IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution: Latin America Conference and Exposition, T and D-LA 2012
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Uruguay; Energy Power Company, UTE, Uruguay; Institute of Electrical, Uruguay; UTE, Uruguay; Institute of Electrical Engineering, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Larrosa, D.; Coppes, E., Faculty of Engineering, Uruguay, Energy Power Company, UTE, Uruguay; Casaravilla, G., UTE, Uruguay, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Uruguay; Chaer, R., Energy Power Company, UTE, Uruguay, Institute of Electrical, Uruguay
Abstract: Hydrothermal systems optimal operation includes a step of optimizing the resources that are valued system storable. This optimization is performed traditionally by a stochastic dynamic programming in which the objective function to minimize is the expected value of future cost of operation, also known as Bellman function. While in theory, minimize the expected value of future cost of operation is "objective" in practice there are many reasons why the actual operation includes additional precautions, sometimes actually taken by operators who are the ones which have responsibility for the consequences of the operation or sometimes made based on safety considerations were not introduced in the optimization of the operation. This work shows the implementation on the platform Simulation of Electric Power Systems of stochastic dynamic programming algorithm for specifying the objective function cost reduction future with a certain probability of exceedance. This work was performed as part of the draft platform enhancements SimSEE with funding from the Energy Sector A(II. The paper presents the results of the operation to minimize the expected value of future cost and minimizing the risk value of 5% of being exceeded. Both operations are compared both costs achieved as in the qualitative aspects. The results allow evaluating the cost of being introduced by risk averse and also identify situations where there are major differences. It also discusses the impact on the marginal cost of system operation with a slogan risk averse. This value is relevant because it is the basis for calculating the Uruguayan market spot price. These scenarios correspond to the operation in 2017 with high penetration of wind energy in the system. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Naccarino J., Yedrzejewski N.
Title: Implementation of AGC in Uruguay - Operational challenges and solution approach
Source title: Proceedings of the 2012 6th IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution: Latin America Conference and Exposition, T and D-LA 2012
Affiliations: Ventyx, ABB Company, Sugar Land, TX 77478, United States; Usinas and Transmisiones Eléctricas (UTE), Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Naccarino, J., Ventyx, ABB Company, Sugar Land, TX 77478, United States; Yedrzejewski, N., Usinas and Transmisiones Eléctricas (UTE), Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: This paper summarizes the implementation of Automatic Generation Control on the new SCADA/EMS system at Usinas y Transmisiones Eléctricas (UTE), to improve the secondary frequency regulation in Uruguay. The primary incentive for UTE to implement AGC is the large increase in wind generation capacity being planned in Uruguay. AGC is an effective tool to compensate the variability and intermittency in the total output of the wind farms. A significant operational challenge in the implementation of AGC in Uruguay was the modeling and control of the Salto Grande Power Plant. Salto Grande is a very large hydro generation facility that is located on the border between Uruguay and Argentina and is jointly-owned between the two countries. The paper also outlines the solution approach being adopted by UTE for Economic Dispatch, Reserve Monitoring, Interchange Scheduling and the Operator Training Simulator. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Miguez J.C.
Title: Welcome message
Source title: Proceedings of the 2012 6th IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution: Latin America Conference and Exposition, T and D-LA 2012
Affiliations: T and D LA 2012, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Miguez, J.C., T and D LA 2012, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Dear IEEE colleagues, Engineers, members of the Latin American power and energy community, is a big pleasure to welcome you to our © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Benech D.P., Cataldo J.
Title: Analysis of the Uruguayan large scale wind energy generation and its energetic
Source title: Proceedings of the 2012 6th IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution: Latin America Conference and Exposition, T and D-LA 2012
Affiliations: Usinas Y Transmisiones Eléctricas del Estado (UTE), Montevideo, Uruguay; Fluid Mechanics and Environmental Engineering Institute, School of Engineering, University of the Republic, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Benech, D.P., Usinas Y Transmisiones Eléctricas del Estado (UTE), Montevideo, Uruguay; Cataldo, J., Fluid Mechanics and Environmental Engineering Institute, School of Engineering, University of the Republic, Uruguay
Abstract: There's a brief description of the Uruguayan wind power installed by 2012, and an analysis of its energetic behavior for the last year. Chronological comparative capacity factor series, and relative wind energy production are shown and analyzed. Two wind farms are selected, and for these, there's an analysis of the correlation of two series: daily energy and hourly power. Finally, by calculating the principal patterns, data is filtered to identify stronger correlations. All the analysis is made based on actual data from the system operator. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Santos A., Aristoy G., Slomovitz D.
Title: A step-up calibration for standard current transformers
Source title: Proceedings of the 2012 6th IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution: Latin America Conference and Exposition, T and D-LA 2012
Affiliations: Electrical Dpt., UTE Laboratory, Montevideo, Uruguay; UTE Laboratory, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Santos, A., Electrical Dpt., UTE Laboratory, Montevideo, Uruguay; Aristoy, G., Electrical Dpt., UTE Laboratory, Montevideo, Uruguay; Slomovitz, D., UTE Laboratory, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Calibration of standard current transformers based on step-up procedures is presented. Starting from one to one ratio, which can be self-calibrated, higher ratios are achieved. Details and results applied to standard transformers of Uruguayan National Metrology Laboratory (UTE) are presented. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Berrutti F., Giusto Á., Artenstein M.
Title: Modal analysis of the Uruguayan power system incorporating large-scale wind generation
Source title: Proceedings of the 2012 6th IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution: Latin America Conference and Exposition, T and D-LA 2012
Affiliations: Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Berrutti, F., Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Giusto, Á., Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Artenstein, M., Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to analyze the small signal stability of the Uruguayan power system on a short to medium term according to the scenarios for the years 2013-2017, in which the transmission network will undergo major changes: first, the inclusion of large quantities of wind power and secondly, the implementation of major infrastructure projects including the construction of the 500kV line from San Carlos - Melo 500kV and 150kV lines Artigas - Rivera and Tacuarembó - Melo of 150kV. In order to understand the global role that will play the integration of wind power in the small signal stability of power system, Uruguayan scenarios of maximum and minimum demand for the years 2013 and 2017 will be analyzed, considering and without considering the incorporation of wind power. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Munsch J.R., Sena C., Giusto A.
Title: Intentional islanding in power systems with dispersed generation
Source title: Proceedings of the 2012 6th IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution: Latin America Conference and Exposition, T and D-LA 2012
Affiliations: IIE, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Munsch, J.R., IIE, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Sena, C., IIE, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Giusto, A., IIE, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Abstract: The expansion and diversification of the Uruguayan energetic infrastructure, with significant penetration of renewable sources is leading to structural changes in the power system, in both transmission and distribution subsystems. These changes impact in the operation criteria and also in the power system protection. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: Benfica J., Bolzani Poehls L.M., Vargas F., Lipovetzky J., Lutenberg A., Gatti E., Hernandez F.
Title: A test platform for dependability analysis of SoCs Exposed to EMI and radiation
Source title: Journal of Electronic Testing: Theory and Applications (JETTA)
Affiliations: Catholic University - PUCRS, Porto Alegre, Brazil; Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Instituto Nacional de Tecnología Industrial - INTI, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Universidad ORT, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Benfica, J., Catholic University - PUCRS, Porto Alegre, Brazil; Bolzani Poehls, L.M., Catholic University - PUCRS, Porto Alegre, Brazil; Vargas, F., Catholic University - PUCRS, Porto Alegre, Brazil; Lipovetzky, J., Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Lutenberg, A., Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Gatti, E., Instituto Nacional de Tecnología Industrial - INTI, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Hernandez, F., Universidad ORT, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: With the IEC 62.132 proposal, the roadmap for standardization of Electromagnetic (EM) immunity measurement methods has reached a high degree of success. The same understanding can be taken from the MIL-STD-883 H for Total Ionizing Dose (TID) radiation. However, no effort has been made to measure the behavior of electronics operating under the combined effects of both, EM noise and TID radiation. For the reasons pointed out, the combined-effect measurements should be mandatory when dealing with Systems-on-Chip (SoCs) devoted to critical applications. In this paper, we present a configurable platform devoted to perform combined tests of EM immunity and TID radiation of SoCs according to the international standards. © 2012 Springer Science+Business Media New York.

Authors: Lasa J., Miguez M., Arnaud A.
Title: Complete integrated cardiac sensing channel for pacemakers
Source title: EAMTA 2012 - Proceedings of the Argentine School of Micro-Nanoelectronics, Technology and Applications 2012
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Lasa, J., Electrical Engineering Department, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay; Miguez, M., Electrical Engineering Department, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay; Arnaud, A., Electrical Engineering Department, Universidad Católica del Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: A novel complete integrated integrated circuit for cardiac sensing is presented. The design eliminates the use of external components, while also keeping up with the safety requirements and low power consumption of implantable medical devices. The work was developed using a high-voltage technology (HV, XC06 technology was selected [1]). The first stage consists of a completely integrated high pass preamplifier, with 25db gain, 4.5μ V rms input referred noise (70-200Hz), and 600nW power consumption. The second stage is a 55-180Hz GmC filter that incorporates the ability to filter input signals with a high common mode input up to 15V. Moreover, a novel full wave precision rectifier and a low power comparator are presented to complete the cardiac sensing channel. © 2012 EDIUNS.

Authors: Alvarez E., Arnaud A.
Title: A cardiac sense channel in a programmable analog device
Source title: EAMTA 2012 - Proceedings of the Argentine School of Micro-Nanoelectronics, Technology and Applications 2012
Affiliations: Universidad Tecnológica Nacional, Capital Federal, Medrano 951, Argentina; Universidad Católica de Uruguay, Av. 8 de Octubre 2738, Montevideo 11600, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Alvarez, E., Universidad Tecnológica Nacional, Capital Federal, Medrano 951, Argentina; Arnaud, A., Universidad Católica de Uruguay, Av. 8 de Octubre 2738, Montevideo 11600, Uruguay
Abstract: A cardiac sense channel implemented in a programmable system on a chip including analog and digital blocks is presented. This architecture relies on switching capacitors and switch matrix to create analog circuits with different, programmable transfer functions, such as filters. Then, an ASIC using the same concept and specifically designed to use in low power, medical implantable devices is simulated. Simulations were carried out using 0.6um technology parameters. © 2012 EDIUNS.

Authors: Silveira L., López G., Chreties C., Crisci M.
Title: Steps towards an early warning model for flood forecasting in Durazno city in Uruguay
Source title: Journal of Flood Risk Management
Affiliations: Department of Fluid Mechanics and Environmental Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Universidad de la República Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Silveira, L., Department of Fluid Mechanics and Environmental Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Universidad de la República Montevideo, Uruguay; López, G., Department of Fluid Mechanics and Environmental Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Universidad de la República Montevideo, Uruguay; Chreties, C., Department of Fluid Mechanics and Environmental Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Universidad de la República Montevideo, Uruguay; Crisci, M., Department of Fluid Mechanics and Environmental Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Universidad de la República Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: A hydrologic-hydrodynamic model of the Yi River basins in Uruguay has been developed as a support tool to the Emergency Coordination Centre of Durazno city. The purpose was to improve the existing decision support system and the emergency planning by providing information on gauge height and its permanence in time, and the risk of flooded areas. Four past flood events of high return period were used for calibration and validation with accurate results. The input data to the operational model in real time are hourly observed rainfall and gauge height, as well as rainfall forecasts by several international sources. The use of predictions from numerical weather forecasts allows for the generation of pre-alert scenarios with larger lead time. These scenarios can warn the emergency coordinators, and thus are of great value to premanage a probable emergency. Operation of a meteorological weather alert issued by the National Meteorological Board is discussed. © 2012 The Chartered Institution of Water and Environmental Management.

Authors: Etcheverry L., Oliver J., Acle J.P.
Title: A soft-core based lab for an introductory microprocessors course
Source title: Proceedings - 2012 Technologies Applied to Electronics Teaching, TAEE 2012
Affiliations: Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Etcheverry, L., Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Oliver, J., Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Acle, J.P., Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: This paper presents a change in the methodology of the laboratory activities in an undergraduate microprocessor systems design course focused on I/O methods and small microprocessors system integration. The laboratory was changed on two main aspects: firstly the assignments are done at home, shortening the time between design activity and experimental verification; secondly a soft-core processor synthesized on an FPGA is exploited to enable the students to exercise hardware design activities on a running system. A suite of development tools combining vendor, third party and in house developed software and hardware cores is presented. These changes are still a work in progress. A transitional version of the course was held during 2011 and the second edition incorporating the rest of the changes is planned for the first half of 2012. Some preliminary results are reported. © 2012 IEEE.

Authors: López-Vázquez C.
Title: Positional accuracy improvement using empirical analytical functions
Source title: Cartography and Geographic Information Science
Affiliations: LatinGEO Lab, SGM + Universidad ORT Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: López-Vázquez, C., LatinGEO Lab, SGM + Universidad ORT Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: We define as Positional Accuracy Improvement the problem of putting together maps A and B of the same area, with B of higher planimetric accuracy. To do so, all objects in A might have to be slightly moved according to a mathematical transformation. Such transformation might ideally be of a specific type, like analytical or conformal functions. We have developed a theory to find a suitable analytical transformation despite it is not well defined because the only data available is the displacement vectors at a limited number of homologue control points. There exists a similar problem in fluid mechanics devoted on estimating the complete velocity field given just values at a limited number of points. We borrowed some ideas from there and introduced them into the positional accuracy improvement problem. We shall demonstrate that it is possible to numerically estimate an analytic function that resembles the given displacement at control points. As a byproduct, an uncertainty estimation is produced, which might help to detect regions of different lineage. The theory has been applied to rural 1:50.000 cartography of Uruguay while trying to diminish the discrepancies against GNSS readings. After the analytic transformation, the RMSE error diminished from 116 m to 48 m. Other problems with similar math requirements are the transformation between geodetic control networks. © 2012 Publishing Technology.

Authors: Pereira A.C.S., Chinellato A.C., Soria A.T., Abreu A.V., Del Mastro N.L., Moura E.A.B.
Title: Comparative study of the sugarcane bagasse fiber/HDPE composite properties using electron-beam and gamma radiation treatments
Source title: TMS Annual Meeting
Affiliations: Nuclear and Energy Research Institute, IPEN-CNEN/SP, 2242 Prof. L. Prestes Av, São Paulo, SP, 05508-000, Brazil; Federal University of ABC, UFABC, 166 Santa Adélia Rua, Santo André, SP, 09210-170, Brazil; Laboratório Tecnologico del Uruguay - Tecnologia de Irradiacion, 6201 Italia Av, Montevideo, 11500, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Pereira, A.C.S., Nuclear and Energy Research Institute, IPEN-CNEN/SP, 2242 Prof. L. Prestes Av, São Paulo, SP, 05508-000, Brazil; Chinellato, A.C., Federal University of ABC, UFABC, 166 Santa Adélia Rua, Santo André, SP, 09210-170, Brazil; Soria, A.T., Laboratório Tecnologico del Uruguay - Tecnologia de Irradiacion, 6201 Italia Av, Montevideo, 11500, Uruguay; Abreu, A.V., Laboratório Tecnologico del Uruguay - Tecnologia de Irradiacion, 6201 Italia Av, Montevideo, 11500, Uruguay; Del Mastro, N.L., Nuclear and Energy Research Institute, IPEN-CNEN/SP, 2242 Prof. L. Prestes Av, São Paulo, SP, 05508-000, Brazil; Moura, E.A.B., Nuclear and Energy Research Institute, IPEN-CNEN/SP, 2242 Prof. L. Prestes Av, São Paulo, SP, 05508-000, Brazil
Abstract: This work presents a comparative study of the thermo-mechanical and morphological properties of sugarcane bagasse fiberZHDPE composite treated with electron-beam and gamma radiation. The composite samples obtained by extrusion and injection molding processes were irradiated at 50 and 90 kGy using either a 1.5 MeV electron beam accelerator or gamma irradiator EMI-9, at room temperature in presence of air. The irradiated and non-irradiated samples were submitted to mechanical and MFI tests, differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), sol-gel analysis and X-Rays Diffraction (XRD) and the correlation between their properties was discussed. Improvement of the bagasse fiber/HDPE composite properties, using electron-beam or gamma radiation, was found.

Authors: FitzGerald J.J., Lago N., Benmerah S., Serra J., Watling C.P., Cameron R.E., Tarte E., Lacour S.P., McMahon S.B., Fawcett J.W.
Title: Erratum: A regenerative microchannel neural interface for recording from and stimulating peripheral axons in vivo (Journal of Neural Engineering (2012) 9, (016010))
