Authors: Hiki H.
Title: Content Production from Digital Archives
Source title: Content Production Technologies
Affiliations: Japan International Cooperation Agency, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Hiki, H., Japan International Cooperation Agency, Uruguay
Abstract: The digitization of audio and visual information brought us various benefits: no quality degradation in copying, high-compression capability, and easy data management. In this chapter these benefits are made good use of for content production from digital archives. Content production requires information management from planning to distribution. Here the several steps involved in content production are described from the point of view of a digital archive. © 2004 John Wiley & Sons Ltd. All Rights Reserved.

Authors: Hasegawa F., Hiki H.
Title: Content Production Technologies
Source title: Content Production Technologies
Affiliations: Tohoku University of Art and Design, Japan; Japan International Cooperation Agency, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Hasegawa, F., Tohoku University of Art and Design, Japan; Hiki, H., Japan International Cooperation Agency, Uruguay
Abstract: We are currently in a digital content era. With the increase in circulation of multimedia content globally via the internet it has lead to the need for reuse of content stored in archives; the utilisation of newly stored materials; partially finished broadcasting programmes and finished content. This book proposes to show solutions to these numerous content issues. It will discuss large scale archives for significant content and a retrieval method for large scale archives and remote editing. The book will also examine the protection of intellectual property rights, which is one of the most important issues facing content owners. Examines the design and implementation of a practical digital content production system Proposes to show solutions to various content issues Covers various retrieval methods for large-scale archives using MPEG-1 streaming technology and remote editing using an original time code Discusses large-scale video archive systems which will enable high speed retrieval and edit functions for large amounts of video data with multi-purpose applications A resource that all broadcast engineers, systems integrators and engineers for equipment manufacturers will find invaluable. The thorough approach to this topic ensures that this title will become the standard reference for R&D specialists in content production and digital archiving. © 2004 John Wiley & Sons Ltd. All Rights Reserved.

Authors: Camni C.T.
Title: Roundabout operation and rights of way [Operación y preferencias en la intersección rotatoria]
Source title: Carreteras
Affiliations: Inforvial (Instituto de Formación Vial de Uruguay), Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Camni, C.T., Inforvial (Instituto de Formación Vial de Uruguay), Uruguay
Abstract: Roundabouts are on ingenious means of solving the complex conflicts of multiple junctions. Conceived prior to motorisation, over time they have undergone comprehensive technical, constructional and operational changes. In spite of their own limitations and problems, roundabouts exist throughout the world and today their use is spreading as a coactive method for traffic calming. It is inconsistent that, in spite of the time that has elapsed, no clear technical operating rules for this type of junction have yet been set up and the fact that roundabouts are not expressly mentioned in traffic regulations. The precise aim of this article is to review this issue with a view to tackling its sensitive aspects.

Authors: Zimberg B., Testuri C.E.
Title: Stochastic analysis of crude oil procurement and processing under uncertain demand of bunker fuel oil
Source title: In Memoriam Lilian Barros - Proceedings of the International Conference on Industrial Logistics, ICIL 2005
Affiliations: Administración Nacional de Combustibles, Alcohol y Portland ANCAP, Humboldt 3900, Montevideo, Uruguay; Instituto de Computación, Universidad de la República, J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Zimberg, B., Administración Nacional de Combustibles, Alcohol y Portland ANCAP, Humboldt 3900, Montevideo, Uruguay; Testuri, C.E., Instituto de Computación, Universidad de la República, J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Bunker fuel oil, one of the products of petroleum refining, has a strong impact on the production process because it drives the availability of heavy residues that depend on the crude quality. Based on the uncertainty of its demand, a stochastic model is proposed, where the benefit of the production is optimized, taking decision on the more suitable raw material, intermediate products and its final blend in order to fulfill the quality and demand requirements of final products. Three different crude qualities are supposed to be available for the first stage decision and their prices include an estimation of the storage cost for different scenarios. The optimum implies the most expensive quality to be bought due to a lack of incentive in the production of extra amounts of fuel oil at a non attractive price. Results are compared with the solution of a deterministic model with mean demand. In spite of being more complex than the deterministic model, the stochastic model solution's shows how the refinery should operate for each scenario of bunker fuel oil demand. Relative value between raw material and products, storage cost and some constraints in the demand have strong impact in the solution. Finally, a first approach to a procedure for building a stochastic model for linear programming packages, of common use in the refining industry, is exposed.

Authors: Fernández V., Sánchez G., Alles A.B.
Title: Surface colours in hand manufactured industrial bricks [Oberflächenfarben handgefertigter industrieller Ziegel]
Source title: ZI, Ziegelindustrie International/Brick and Tile Industry International
Affiliations: Universidad de la República, Fak. Für Ingenieurwesen, Herrea y Reissig 565, 11300 Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Fernández, V., Universidad de la República, Fak. Für Ingenieurwesen, Herrea y Reissig 565, 11300 Montevideo, Uruguay; Sánchez, G., Universidad de la República, Fak. Für Ingenieurwesen, Herrea y Reissig 565, 11300 Montevideo, Uruguay; Alles, A.B., Universidad de la República, Fak. Für Ingenieurwesen, Herrea y Reissig 565, 11300 Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Hand manufactured industrial bricks from Uruguayan brickworks were sintered in a laboratory kiln at different temperatures with different soaking times. It was established that the firing temperature and kiln atmosphere affect the surface colour of the bricks and that the soaking time during firing influences the occurrence of black cores in the bricks. It was demonstrated that the light surface colours found frequently on the market can be attributed to drying efflorescence.

Authors: Olivera A., Viera O.
Title: Solving the vehicle routing problem with multiple trips by adaptive memory programming
Source title: In Memoriam Lilian Barros - Proceedings of the International Conference on Industrial Logistics, ICIL 2005
Affiliations: Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Herrera y Reissig 525, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Olivera, A., Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Herrera y Reissig 525, Montevideo, Uruguay; Viera, O., Instituto de Computación, Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Herrera y Reissig 525, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: In the Vehicle Routing Problem with Multiple Trips, besides the classic Vehicle Routing Problem constraints, each vehicle is allowed to perform several routes in the same planning period. In this paper we propose an adaptive memory algorithm to solve this problem. High quality solutions were found over a set of benchmark problem instances, including some new best solutions.

Authors: Robledo F., Maba R., Manzo I., Nachman D.
Title: Using GRASP for designing low-cost access topologies
Source title: In Memoriam Lilian Barros - Proceedings of the International Conference on Industrial Logistics, ICIL 2005
Affiliations: Facultad de Ingeniería, UDELAR, Julio Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay; Quanam Company, Canelones 1370, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Robledo, F., Facultad de Ingeniería, UDELAR, Julio Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay; Maba, R., Quanam Company, Canelones 1370, Montevideo, Uruguay; Manzo, I., Quanam Company, Canelones 1370, Montevideo, Uruguay; Nachman, D., Quanam Company, Canelones 1370, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: In this paper, we concentrate on topological planning process of the large-scale access network associated to a Wide Area Network (WAN). The introduced access network design problem (ANDP, Access Network Design Problem) is NP-hard, and can be modeled as a variant of the Steiner Problem in Graphs (SPG). We propose a Greedy Randomized Adaptive Search Procedure (GRASP) in order to approximately solve the proposed ANDP. The performance of our heuristic was tested on a testing set generated by customizing 210 SPG instances with different topological characteristics from SteinLib repository. The optimum values of the extracted SPG instances provide lower bounds for the designed ANDP instances. The numerical results were very goods, obtaining low average gaps with respect to the lower bounds in most of the problem classes, and reaching the optimum in 44 cases (more than 20% of the problem set).

Authors: De Sensale G.R., Sabalsagaray B.S., Cabrera J., Marziotte L., Romay C.
Title: Effect of the constituents on the properties of SCC in fresh and hardened state
Source title: Structural Concrete and Time - Proceedings of the fib Symposium
Affiliations: Universidad de la Repüblica, Facultad de lngenieria, J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: De Sensale, G.R., Universidad de la Repüblica, Facultad de lngenieria, J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay; Sabalsagaray, B.S., Universidad de la Repüblica, Facultad de lngenieria, J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay; Cabrera, J., Universidad de la Repüblica, Facultad de lngenieria, J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay; Marziotte, L., Universidad de la Repüblica, Facultad de lngenieria, J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay; Romay, C., Universidad de la Repüblica, Facultad de lngenieria, J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Lack of fillers in Uruguay, usually substituted by Portland Cement, make SelfCompacting Concrete very expensive. Electrofilter powder (EP) trom one local cement industry was found to be one of the most appropriate fillers so it was chosen for the study. Two SCC m ixes, with and without EP, were analyzed and then compared. In fresh state were used Slump Cone, U-Box, L-box, V Funnel and Filling vessel tests; and in hardened state were evaluated compressive strength, modulus of rupture, air permeability, electrical resistivity, water impermeability and capillary suction. The influence of u sing different coarse aggregates was studied in both mixes. The constituents of the SCC influence its behavior in fresh and hardened state, and the use of EP reduces its cost.

Authors: Slomovitz D., De Souza H.
Title: Shielded electronic current transformer
Source title: CPEM Digest (Conference on Precision Electromagnetic Measurements)
Affiliations: Departamento de Ingenierí Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingenierí, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; UTE Laboratorio, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Slomovitz, D., Departamento de Ingenierí Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingenierí, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; De Souza, H., UTE Laboratorio, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: A current transformer with nominal ratio 10 A to 10 mA, intended for low frequencies applications, was developed. It includes an electronic device to reduce the magnetizing current, and a continuos shield in the secondary winding in order to eliminate the effect of stray capacitances. These lead to high accuracy results (ratio errors and phase-displacements in the order of 10-6). It is proposed to leave the cable-shield potential floating. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Curtin D., Hegarty S.P., Goulding D., Houlihan J., Busch Th., Masoller C., Huyet G.
Title: Bistable systems with noise and delay
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Physics Department, National University of Ireland, University College Cork, Ireland; Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Igua 4225, Montevideo 11400, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Curtin, D., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, University College Cork, Ireland; Hegarty, S.P., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, University College Cork, Ireland; Goulding, D., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, University College Cork, Ireland; Houlihan, J., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, University College Cork, Ireland; Busch, Th., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, University College Cork, Ireland; Masoller, C., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Igua 4225, Montevideo 11400, Uruguay; Huyet, G., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, University College Cork, Ireland
Abstract: The polarisation dynamics of vertical cavity surface emitting lasers (VCSELs) in the bistable regime is well described by Kramers theory for noise induced transitions. By employing feedback, a memory mechanism can be introduced, which make the dynamics of the system non-Markovian. Here we analyse theoretically and experimentally the residence time distribution of the bistable systems in the presence of noise and time-delayed feedback, using an opto-electronic feedback cycle for a VCSEL. We demonstrate and explain various non-exponential features of the residence time distribution using a continuous as well as a two-state model. Additionally we compare the results to an electronic Schmitt trigger, which represents an experimental realization of the two-state model.

Authors: Konor C.S., Boezio G.C., Mechoso C.R., Arakawa A.
Title: Evaluation of a new PBL parameterization with emphasis in surface fluxes
Source title: 13th Conference on Interactions of the Sea and Atmosphere
Affiliations: Department of Atmospheric Science, Colorado State University, United States; Department of Atmospheric Sciences, University of California, Los Angeles, United States; IMFIA, Universidad de la Republica, Uruguay; Colorado State University, Department of Atmospheric Science, Fort Collins, CO 80523-1371, United States
Authors with affiliations: Konor, C.S., Department of Atmospheric Science, Colorado State University, United States, Colorado State University, Department of Atmospheric Science, Fort Collins, CO 80523-1371, United States; Boezio, G.C., Department of Atmospheric Sciences, University of California, Los Angeles, United States, IMFIA, Universidad de la Republica, Uruguay; Mechoso, C.R., Department of Atmospheric Sciences, University of California, Los Angeles, United States; Arakawa, A., Department of Atmospheric Sciences, University of California, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: A new PBL parameterization that was implemented and tested in the UCLA AGCM was described. The new parameterization introduces multiple layers between the PBL top and the earth surface, allowing for vertical shears and deviations from well-mixed profiles within the PBL. The PBL parameterization was based on Randall and Schubert, in which the bulk PBL turbulent kinetic energy is predicted and used for the computation of the structure fluxes. It was found that in the PBL the entrainment formulas were explicit and make use of the PBL TKE, and it also considered reviewed bulk aerodynamic formulas for the computation of the surface fluxes.

Authors: Langwagen G., Lopes A.
Title: Sampled continuous time filter banks and frame theory
Source title: Proceedings of the IASTED International Conference on Circuits, Signals, and Systems
Affiliations: Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad ORT Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay; Faculdade de Engenharia, Elet. e de Computação, UNICAMP, Campinas SP, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Langwagen, G., Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad ORT Uruguay, Montevideo, Uruguay; Lopes, A., Faculdade de Engenharia, Elet. e de Computação, UNICAMP, Campinas SP, Brazil
Abstract: Our proposal is to use a sampled continuous time filter bank to decompose in time and frequency non band limited functions. We present the proposed structure of the analysis bank and we indicate how to use another synthesis bank to obtain a continuous time output. We relate this proposal to standard time frequency analysis and we explain the connection between the construction of perfect reconstruction systems and the mathematical theory of Gabor frames. In this contribution we show that the consequence of using causal filters is that the output will always be delayed by a multiple of the inverse of the spacing of the filters in the frequency domain. We also suggest some relations between the widths of the filters impulse responses and the parameters of the lattice.

Authors: Martín A., Seroussi G., Weinberger M.J.
Title: Linear time universal coding of tree sources via FSM closure
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory - Proceedings
Affiliations: Instituto de Computación, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Hewlett-Packard Laboratories, 1501 Page Mill Road, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States
Authors with affiliations: Martín, A., Instituto de Computación, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Seroussi, G., Hewlett-Packard Laboratories, 1501 Page Mill Road, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States; Weinberger, M.J., Hewlett-Packard Laboratories, 1501 Page Mill Road, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States
Abstract: The first algorithm for linear time encoding/decoding of a twice-universal code of tree sources was presented. The algorithmic tools employed in the derivation and the information-theoretic implications was investigated. The two basic computational drawbacks of tree models were identified. The class of tree models were generalized to address the first drawback and the finite-memory source (FSM) closure of a GCT T was characterized to address the second drawback.

Authors: Hong Y., Masoller C., Spencer P.S., Shore K.A.
Title: Optical feedback control of polarization switching in vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers
Source title: LEOS Summer Topical Meeting
Affiliations: University of Wales, Bangor, School of Informatics, Bangor LL57 1UT, United Kingdom; Instituto de Fisica, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la Republica, Igua 4225, Montevideo 11400, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Hong, Y., University of Wales, Bangor, School of Informatics, Bangor LL57 1UT, United Kingdom; Masoller, C., Instituto de Fisica, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la Republica, Igua 4225, Montevideo 11400, Uruguay; Spencer, P.S., University of Wales, Bangor, School of Informatics, Bangor LL57 1UT, United Kingdom; Shore, K.A., University of Wales, Bangor, School of Informatics, Bangor LL57 1UT, United Kingdom
Abstract: The use of vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers (VCSEL) in optical communication systems was analyzed. The polarization switching could be suppressed by the application of polarization-selective optical feedback. X-polarized light was used to refer the light whose polarization direction was in parallel to the dominant free-running VCSEL polarization near threshold. The polarization-selective optical feedback could be used to eliminate the polarization switching in VCSEL.

Authors: Houlihan J., Huyet G., Busch Th., Hegarty S.P., Goulding D., Curtin D., Masoller C.
Title: Distribution of residence times in bistable noisy systems with time-delayed feedback
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Physics Department, National University of Ireland, Cork, Ireland; Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Igua 4225, Montevideo 11400, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Houlihan, J., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, Cork, Ireland; Huyet, G., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, Cork, Ireland; Busch, Th., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, Cork, Ireland; Hegarty, S.P., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, Cork, Ireland; Goulding, D., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, Cork, Ireland; Curtin, D., Physics Department, National University of Ireland, Cork, Ireland; Masoller, C., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Igua 4225, Montevideo 11400, Uruguay
Abstract: We analyse theoretically and experimentally the residence time distribution of bistable systems in the presence of noise and time-delayed feedback. The feedback provides a memory mechanism for the system which leads to non-Markovian dynamics. We demonstrate and explain various non-exponential features of the residence time distribution using a two-state as well as a continuous model. The experimental results are based on a Schmitt Trigger where the feedback is provided by a computer generated delay loop and on a semiconductor laser with opto-electronic feedback.

Authors: Cabeza C., Negreira C., Gibiat V.
Title: Coexistence of localized structures and patterns in Faraday instability for high dissipative fluids
Source title: International Journal of Bifurcation and Chaos in Applied Sciences and Engineering
Affiliations: Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, CP 11400, Iguá 4225, Uruguay; LAMI University Paul Sabatier, 118, route de Narbonne, 31062 Toulouse, France
Authors with affiliations: Cabeza, C., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, CP 11400, Iguá 4225, Uruguay; Negreira, C., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, CP 11400, Iguá 4225, Uruguay; Gibiat, V., LAMI University Paul Sabatier, 118, route de Narbonne, 31062 Toulouse, France
Abstract: We present an experimental study of the generation of strongly localized structures that propagate on the surface of a dissipative fluid. We excited a layer of fluid with a vertical periodic acceleration field, and a parametric instability occurs when a certain threshold value is achieved. This process is known as Faraday Instability and the temporal evolution of the system obeys a period-doubling route. For a highly dissipative fluid we observed two new interesting phenomena: the generation of high spatially localized structures which propagate on top of the stripes of stationary pattern, and a periodic window which occurs after the system reached spatiotemporal chaos.

Authors: Griot M., Tucci G., Beizarena P., Remersaro S.
Title: Analysis and improvements to MATE algorithm
Source title: IEEE International Performance, Computing and Communications Conference, Proceedings
Affiliations: IIE, Facultad de Ingeniería, UDELAR, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Griot, M., IIE, Facultad de Ingeniería, UDELAR, Uruguay; Tucci, G., IIE, Facultad de Ingeniería, UDELAR, Uruguay; Beizarena, P., IIE, Facultad de Ingeniería, UDELAR, Uruguay; Remersaro, S., IIE, Facultad de Ingeniería, UDELAR, Uruguay
Abstract: This paper describes an implementation, analysis and improvements to MATE (MPLS Adaptive Traffic Engineering) algorithm. MATE is an on-line load balancing algorithm. As MATE was originally thought for constant average incoming traffic, the first improvement is the wage of an adaptive update step size for time varying traffic. The second one modifies the time interval between updates to adequate itself to the traffic characteristics and calculate the amount of measurements in each interval to have a reliable statistic. The original algorithm and the new version, which will be called MATE-TV (MATE for Time-Varying traffic), were implemented in a LINUX - MPLS network, using the 'mpls-linux' packet distributed by Source Forge.

Authors: Lezama A., Valente P., Failache H., Martinelli M., Cruz L.S., Felimto D., Nussenzveig P.
Title: Noise spectroscopy of nonlinear magneto-optical resonances
Source title: OSA Trends in Optics and Photonics Series
Affiliations: Instituto de Fisica, Facultad de Ingennieria, C. Postal 30, 11000 Montevideo, Uruguay; Instituto de Física, Universidade de Sao Paulo, C. Postal 66318, 05315-970, Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Lezama, A., Instituto de Fisica, Facultad de Ingennieria, C. Postal 30, 11000 Montevideo, Uruguay; Valente, P., Instituto de Fisica, Facultad de Ingennieria, C. Postal 30, 11000 Montevideo, Uruguay; Failache, H., Instituto de Fisica, Facultad de Ingennieria, C. Postal 30, 11000 Montevideo, Uruguay; Martinelli, M., Instituto de Física, Universidade de Sao Paulo, C. Postal 66318, 05315-970, Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil; Cruz, L.S., Instituto de Física, Universidade de Sao Paulo, C. Postal 66318, 05315-970, Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil; Felimto, D., Instituto de Física, Universidade de Sao Paulo, C. Postal 66318, 05315-970, Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil; Nussenzveig, P., Instituto de Física, Universidade de Sao Paulo, C. Postal 66318, 05315-970, Sao Paulo, SP, Brazil
Abstract: Light noise spectroscopy is shown to be a sensitive tool for the detection of nonlinear magneto-optical resonances due to coherence in the ground state of alkaline atoms. Experiments with Rb and theoretical models are presented. © 2003 Optical Society of America.

Authors: Robledo F., Rubino G., Cancela H., Robledo F.
Title: Finding steiner trees with degree 1 terminal nodes
Source title: IEICE Electronics Express
Affiliations: ARMOR team, IRISA/INRIA Rennes Campus de Beaulieu 35042, Rennes, France; Facultad de Ingeniería Uruguay, Universidad de la República J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Robledo, F., ARMOR team, IRISA/INRIA Rennes Campus de Beaulieu 35042, Rennes, France; Rubino, G., ARMOR team, IRISA/INRIA Rennes Campus de Beaulieu 35042, Rennes, France; Cancela, H., Facultad de Ingeniería Uruguay, Universidad de la República J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay; Robledo, F., Facultad de Ingeniería Uruguay, Universidad de la República J. Herrera y Reissig 565, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: We consider in this work a variant of the Steiner Problem in Graphs (SPG) with the additional restriction that terminal nodes must have degree 1. We customize the Greedy Randomized Adaptive Search Procedure (GRASP) metaheuristic, testing its performance on a large problem set obtained by modifying 182 SPG instances from the SteinLib repository. The GRASP obtained good results, with low average gaps with respect to known lower bounds in most of the problem classes, and attaining the optimum in 44 cases (24% of the problem set). © 2004, The Institute of Electronics, Information and Communication Engineers. All rights reserved.

Authors: Montaño J., Peel E.
Title: Geothermalism in the Guarani Aquifer System, Uruguay
Source title: Transactions - Geothermal Resources Council
Affiliations: Universidad de la República, Facultad de Ciencias, Departamento de Geología, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Montaño, J., Universidad de la República, Facultad de Ciencias, Departamento de Geología, Uruguay; Peel, E., Universidad de la República, Facultad de Ciencias, Departamento de Geología, Uruguay
Abstract: The amount of the hydric reserve and the physical and chemical characteristics of the Guaraní Aquifer System (GAS) turn it in an almost unique groundwater hydric resource worldwide. It has a hydric potential of the order of 40.000 km3 and it presents, to a large extent of the area that occupies (1,181,000 km2), low enthalpy thermalism conditions and important volumes of flow (from 30 to 340 m3/h). These attributes make the GAS an strategic resource, and give it a great social-economic importance. Thus, it is necessary to develop a Regional Managment Plan, which comprises the four countries that share the GAS (Argentina, Brasil, Paraguay and Uruguay), assuring its conservation and aiming to a sustainable use of the GAS.

Authors: Molas M.C., Armentano R., Bia D., Zócalo Y., Craiem D., Risk M.R.
Title: Enhanced Venous Compliance Sensibility at Physiological Ranges of Pressure: Experimental Validation of a Biphasic Model
Source title: Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology - Proceedings
Affiliations: Universidad Favaloro, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Harvard Medical School, BIDMC, Boston, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Molas, M.C., Universidad Favaloro, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Armentano, R., Universidad Favaloro, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Bia, D., Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Zócalo, Y., Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Craiem, D., Universidad Favaloro, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Risk, M.R., Harvard Medical School, BIDMC, Boston, MA, United States
Abstract: Recent non-invasive studies in humans have shown the relationship between venous compliance and pressure within the physiological range to be best described by a biphasic model. This model sets a breakpoint pressure that splits the pressure range in two different linear compliance phases. Six ovine internal jugular vein segments were studied in-vitro under pulsatile pressure and flow conditions achieved by a mock circulation loop. Instantaneous pressure (Konigsberg) and diameter (sonomicrometry) signals were assessed in a wide range (0-60mmHg) of intravascular pressure. For each segment the low pressure range was set between 0mmHg and the breakpoint pressure and the high pressure range from the breakpoint pressure to 60mmHg. The mean venous negative slope ∂C/∂P for low pressures was significantly steeper than for high pressures (p<0.01). The calculated r for the linear trend lines resulted r =0.96±0.03 (p<0.01) for low pressures and r =0.79±0.07 (p<0.05) for high pressures, validating the biphasic model in-vitro. The ∂C/∂P would describe a compliance change following a pressure variation and might be adopted as a compliance sensibility index.

Authors: Núñez I., Arzúa A., Negreira C.
Title: Improving pulsed dark field method to study ultrasonic phenomena
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Ultrasonics Symposium
Affiliations: Laboratorio de Acusto-Optica, Instituto de Física, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Núñez, I., Laboratorio de Acusto-Optica, Instituto de Física, Montevideo, Uruguay; Arzúa, A., Laboratorio de Acusto-Optica, Instituto de Física, Montevideo, Uruguay; Negreira, C., Laboratorio de Acusto-Optica, Instituto de Física, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Using Pulsed Dark Field (PDF) method to analyze ultrasound fields presents some advantages with respect to the traditional Schlieren method, and with respect to the non-pulsed dark field method. First, the circular black spot used to stop the zero-order of diffracted light (Dark Field method) allows us to observe phase modulations in all directions perpendicular to the propagation of the beam. The classical "knife edge" of the Schlieren method shows phase modulations principally in one direction. This one is normal to the edge of the knife and normal to the light beam. On the other hand, PDF method uses short time illumination triggered by the acoustic pulse. This allows observing elastic fields in pulsed regime and we can evaluate the evolution of such pulse inside homogeneous and heterogeneous media. In this paper we apply PDF method to determine the conditions of change from single to multiple scattering. A 2.25 MHz transducer in water emits a wide-band ultrasonic pulse. By varying the distribution of scatterers (cylindrical wires of 1.2 mm diameter) it is possible to generate the conditions necessary for loosing coherence in the pulse. We use a 10 mW He-Ne laser, an acousto-optic modulator (Neos Bragg cell driven by Neos N21080) triggered by the acoustic pulse generator (Sonic), two lenses of focal length 850 mm and diameter 74 mm, a black spot of diameter.5 mm, a CCD camera (EDC-1000HR, Electrim Co.) with resolution 244×753 pixels.

Authors: Fornaro L., Cuña A., Aguiar I., Férez M., Mussio L.
Title: Bismuth tri-iodide polycrystalline films as beta direct and digital imaging detectors for medical applications
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium Conference Record
Affiliations: Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Fornaro, L., Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Cuña, A., Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Aguiar, I., Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Férez, M., Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Mussio, L., Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay
Abstract: We report here the use of bismuth tri-iodide polycrystalline films as beta direct and digital detectors for medical imaging applications. First, films were grown by the physical vapor deposition method on glass substrates 2″× 2″ in size, with gold previously deposited as rear contact. For the growth, bismuth tri-iodide 99.99% was heated at 280 °C and 400 mmHg of Ar initial pressure, during 20 - 60 hours (for different film thickness). Film thickness gave values between 20 and 50 μm (± 5%). Film grain size was 10 μm ( ± 10%). Detectors were made by depositing gold onto the films as front contact (areas 7 -100 mm2) and then performing acrylic encapsulation. Resistivities up to 3 × 1015 Ωcm were obtained for these detectors. The film response to beta radiation was checked by irradiating the films with beta emitters of different energies and doses and for several bias voltages applied to the detectors. Response correlates with the expected one, considering film thickness and the stopping power of the material, and results to be linear with the exposure rate. The ability of distinguish beta radiation in the presence of a gamma background was also checked. A phantom with a linear beta source arrangement was used to check the films feasibility of imaging separate tumors.

Authors: Molas M.C., Armentano R., Bia D., Zócalo Y., Laviña G., Craiem D., Voliovici E., Bonilla F., Cabrera-Fischer E.I.
Title: Isobaric Elastic Mismatch Among Native Arteries and Conduits Used In Systemic Vascular By-Pass
Source title: Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology - Proceedings
Affiliations: Departamento de Fisiología, Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Universidad Favaloro, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Depto. Basico de Cirugia, Facultad de Medicina, Univ. de la Rep. Montevideo, Uruguay

Basico de Cirugia, Facultad de Medicina, Univ. de la Rep. Montevideo, Uruguay; Bonilla, F., Depto. Basico de Cirugia, Facultad de Medicina, Univ. de la Rep. Montevideo, Uruguay; Cabrera-Fischer, E.I., Universidad Favaloro, Buenos Aires, Argentina
Abstract: An arterial bypass might be either carried out with a venous segment or using a polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) graft. Different patency rates were reported depending on the chosen method. Our objective was to compare the elastic properties of three different segment: A) expanded synthetic polytetrafluoroethylene (ePTFE) grafts, B) jugular veins, and C) systemic arteries (femoral artery). Pressure (P) and diameter signals were measured in six ovine venous, arterial, and ePTFE segments, mounted in a circulation mock and perfused at systemic pressure and stretch rate. Elastic modulus (E inc) was calculated at 100mmHg using a pressure and diameter analysis. At systemic P level, both venous and ePTFE were stiffer than the artery (p<0.05), but venous Einc was more compliant than the ePTFE (p<0.05). The elastic mismatch was higher (p<0.05) between a ePTFE graft and the artery than between the vein and the artery. This could explain the major incidence of arterial by-pass failure reported when a ePTFE graft is chosen.

Authors: Craiem D., Armentano R., Grignola J.C., Bia D., Molas M.C., Ginés F.
Title: Pressure Transfer Functions to Study Ventricular-Arterial Interaction in Systemic and Pulmonary Circulation
Source title: Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology - Proceedings
Affiliations: Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Universidad Favaloro, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Univ. Tecnológica Nacional, Facultad Regional Buenos Aires, Argentina

Tecnológica Nacional, Facultad Regional Buenos Aires, Argentina; Armentano, R., Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay, Universidad Favaloro, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Grignola, J.C., Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Bia, D., Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Molas, M.C., Universidad Favaloro, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Ginés, F., Facultad de Medicina, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: The heart pumps pressure and flow signals with relevant amount of frequency components cushioned along the arterial system. A pressure transfer function approach was designed to evaluate the Ventricular-Arterial Interaction. Two transfer functions were calculated relating ventricular to arterial pressure. A frequency response analysis followed the time-domain adaptation. Additionally, a viscoelastic model was proposed to characterize the arterial wall mechanical behavior, using the elastic (E) and viscous (η) moduli. Six merino sheep were instrumented and anesthetized. Pressure measurements were registered in both ventricles, in aorta and in the pulmonary artery. Diameters (sonomicrometry) were measured in both arteries. The frequency transfer function asymptotic negative slope, describing the attenuation within the dynamic range, resulted 5 times greater in aorta (p<0.05), what presents the systemic as a more selective circuit than the pulmonary. E and η resulted higher (p<0.05) in aorta than in the pulmonary artery whereas E/η) was similar. The viscoelastic results might indicate a similar segmental (unit-cell) response in both arteries. The enhanced cushioning ability of the left circuit with respect to the right, might be understood as a more selective vascular filtering system. This filtering performance might be related to the functional length of unit-cell responses along the systemic circulation.

Authors: Saucedo E., Fornaro L., Sochinskii N.V., Cuña A., Corregidor V., Granados D., Diéguez E.
Title: Heavy metal doping of CdTe crystals
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium Conference Record
Affiliations: Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Departamento de Física, Univ. Autónoma de Madrid, Madrid 28049, Spain; Inst. de Microelectronica de Madrid, CNM-CSIC, c/ Isaac Newton 8 (PTM), Tres Cantos,28760, Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Saucedo, E., Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay, Departamento de Física, Univ. Autónoma de Madrid, Madrid 28049, Spain; Fornaro, L., Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Sochinskii, N.V., Inst. de Microelectronica de Madrid, CNM-CSIC, c/ Isaac Newton 8 (PTM), Tres Cantos,28760, Madrid, Spain; Cuña, A., Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Corregidor, V., Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Granados, D., Inst. de Microelectronica de Madrid, CNM-CSIC, c/ Isaac Newton 8 (PTM), Tres Cantos,28760, Madrid, Spain; Diéguez, E., Radiochemistry Department, Compound Semiconductors Group, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay
Abstract: CdTe crystals doped with several heavy metals (Hg, Tl, Pb and Bi) in the concentration range of 1017-1018 at/cm3 have been grown by the vertical Bridgman method. The structural quality and uniformity of the crystals was verified by chemical determination of etch pits density and by X-ray rocking curves. Inductively coupled plasma-Mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS) was employed for evaluating the dopant concentration. Low temperature photoluminescence (PL) measurements of the crystals were performed in the 1.2-1.6 eV energy range. The crystal electrical properties were studied by Hall and I-V measurements. The obtained PL data show a domination of (D-X) and (DAP) lines in CdTe crystals, suggesting n-type conductivity and the presence of a compensation mechanism due to the heavy dopant incorporation. Investigating the 1.4 eV band, we obtained the Huang-Rhys parameter, the principal energy of zero phonon line and the energy of longitudinal optical phonon for each dopant. Impurities were measured by ICP-MS. A particular PL line at 1.473 eV, correlated to MTe (M = heavy metal) defect centers, was found. It was found that the heavy metal doped CdTe crystals have resistivity values in the range 107-1010 Ω.cm, with maximum values for Bi and Hg doped materials. Also these materials show a higher dark current stability than the ones doped with the other heavy metals. Detectors made from Hg doped crystals gave response to X and γ radiation.

Authors: Toral R., Mirasso C.R., Masoller C., Ciszak M., Calvo O.
Title: Anticipated synchronization in neuronal systems subject to noise

Mateu Orfila, Campus UIB, 07122-Palma de Mallorca, Spain; Calvo, O., Departament de Física, Universitat de les Illes Balears, Campus UIB, 07122-Palma de Mallorca, Spain
Abstract: We report the observation of synchrony in two unidirectionally coupled (master-slave) model neurons (implemented by electronic circuits) in a noisy environment. Both neurons are subjected to the same random stimulus, and there is a recurrent inhibitory delayed connection in the slave neuron. We observe that synchrony occurs shifted in time, such that the slave neuron anticipates, i.e., forecasts, the response of the master neuron. By incorporating the effects of unidirectional coupling, delayed feedback and common noise into models of two spiking neurons, we are able to simulate successfully the experimental observations.

Authors: Garbusi E., Ferrari J.A.
Title: Faraday rotation measurement with photorefractive Bi12TiO20: Comment
Source title: Optics and Laser Technology
Affiliations: Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingeniería, Julio Herrera y Reissig 565, CP Montevideo, Uruguay

Abstract: In a recent paper (Opt. Laser Technol. 34 (2002) 605) Anand and Narayanamurthy described a method for measurement of Faraday rotations using a photorefractive Bi12TiO20. The effects they observed have nothing to do with the source intensity nor with the photorefractive nature of the crystal. The same effect could be obtained without the use of a photorefractive crystal by simple rotation of the analyzer. © 2003 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: López C.
Title: Digital rights management of geo-datasets: Protection against map piracy in the digital era
Source title: GIM International
Affiliations: GIM International, Universitario Autonomo del Sur, Montevideo 1225, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: López, C., GIM International, Universitario Autonomo del Sur, Montevideo 1225, Uruguay
Abstract: The creation of good quality maps (or geo-datasets in general) is a complex and expensive task. Suitable protection against piracy has thus long been a subject of interest within the cartographic community. When national mapping agencies operate according to the cost recovery model map piracy becomes an even more significant threat. The author addresses an intertwined protection solution involving both technological and legal means.

Abstract: This reports on the surface attraction exerted onto Cs(8P), as measured through the selective reflection spectroscopy (SR) technique via a one-photon excitation at 388 nm from the ground state. In a series of experiments on the Cs (6S1/2-8P3/2) transition in front of a sapphire surface, the accuracy in the van der Waals evaluation, and with an improved fitting method, should be on the order of 10%. Further developments, expected to be reported too, concern the fine structure component Cs (6S1/2-8P3/2), along with a study of SR spectroscopy at various interfaces.

Authors: Sciamanna M., Masoller C., Abraham N.B., Rogister F., Mégret P., Blondel M.
Title: Different regimes of low-frequency fluctuations in vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Serv. Electromagnet. Telecommun., Faculté Polytechnique de Mons, 31 Boulevard Dolez, B-7000 Mons, Belgium; Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Igua 4225, Montevideo 11400, Uruguay; DePauw University, Greencastle, IN 46135-0037, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sciamanna, M., Serv. Electromagnet. Telecommun., Faculté Polytechnique de Mons, 31 Boulevard Dolez, B-7000 Mons, Belgium; Masoller, C., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Igua 4225, Montevideo 11400, Uruguay; Abraham, N.B., DePauw University, Greencastle, IN 46135-0037, United States; Rogister, F., Serv. Electromagnet. Telecommun., Faculté Polytechnique de Mons, 31 Boulevard Dolez, B-7000 Mons, Belgium; Mégret, P., Serv. Electromagnet. Telecommun., Faculté Polytechnique de Mons, 31 Boulevard Dolez, B-7000 Mons, Belgium; Blondel, M., Serv. Electromagnet. Telecommun., Faculté Polytechnique de Mons, 31 Boulevard Dolez, B-7000 Mons, Belgium
Abstract: We show that vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers (VCSEL) subject to a polarization preserving optical feedback from a long external cavity may exhibit two different types of low-frequency fluctuations (LFF) regime. In both types, the total intensity shows random drops and then recovers gradually to its original value. But the two LFF types are clearly distinguished by the behavior of the x- and y-linearly polarized (LP) modes. Type I LFF is characterized by the fact that the x- and y-LP modes compete with nearly equal power, while type II LFF is characterized by intensity dropouts in the dominant polarization mode and intensity bursts in the depressed mode. We analyze the parameter regions in which these different LFF occur and characterize them further. Our numerical results suggest that a transition from one LFF type to the other may be experimentally observed by modifying the frequency difference and/or the gain-to-loss ratio of the two LP modes. The LFF we present is an example of vectorial chaos, which may be of use for multichannel secure communication systems using chaotic light.

Authors: Santo C., Fuentes J., Curbelo J.M.
Title: Estimation of uncertainty in analytical balances - Comparison of mass measurements performed in analytical balances (LATU-1999)

Abstract: The current paper provides the details of the main sources of uncertainty that occur when conventional mass determinations are performed in analytical balances. The data presented correspond to the calibration of 18 analytical balances that belong to LATU, together with the detailed quantification of each of the sources of uncertainty. The results of a comparison of conventional mass measurement performed in those balances with a Teflon sample are assessed, considering their uncertainty values.

Authors: Andia M.E., Lagos G.E., Danielson L.J.
Title: The challenges posed by mine closure in Chile
Source title: 4th International Conference COPPER 99-COBRE 99
Affiliations: Centre for Mining, Catholic University of Chile, Avda. Vicuñna Mackenna 4860, Macul, Santiago, Chile; Intl. Development Res. Centre (IDRC), Plaza Cagancha 1335, 6379 Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Andia, M.E., Centre for Mining, Catholic University of Chile, Avda. Vicuñna Mackenna 4860, Macul, Santiago, Chile; Lagos, G.E., Centre for Mining, Catholic University of Chile, Avda. Vicuñna Mackenna 4860, Macul, Santiago, Chile; Danielson, L.J., Intl. Development Res. Centre (IDRC), Plaza Cagancha 1335, 6379 Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: In Chile, a significant amount of mining takes place in varied geographical environments. Mining activity extends from copper and gold deposits located in the Atacama Desert 4.500 meters above sea level to underground coal workings beneath the sea floor. This diversity in location and environment presents many challenges in the development of competitive and environmentally sustainable mining activities. An important future issue will be how to close these mines in an appropriate way once economically exploitable ore reserves have been exhausted. This poses challenges for both the government and companies alike, considering that Chilean law currently lacks legislation specific to mine closure. This paper examines the risks associated with mine closure based on international experience, and identifies those risks specific to Chilean regions. The main regions in Chile where mine closure legislation should be applied are identified.

Authors: Fornaro L., Saucedo E., Mussio L., Gancharov A., Guimaraes F., Hernandes A.
Title: Lead iodide platelets: Correlation between surface, optical and electrical properties with X and γ ray spectrometric performance
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium and Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: Faculty of Chemistry, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Fornaro, L., Faculty of Chemistry, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Saucedo, E., Faculty of Chemistry, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Mussio, L., Faculty of Chemistry, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Gancharov, A., Faculty of Chemistry, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Guimaraes, F., Faculty of Chemistry, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay; Hernandes, A., Faculty of Chemistry, University of Uruguay, Montevideo, 11800, Uruguay
Abstract: Lead iodide platelets grown by Physical Vapor Deposition were characterized by several properties related to spectrometric performance. Platelets were grown from both synthesized lead iodide without purification and then purified by repeated evaporation. The growth was performed by heating the starting material at vacuum (10 -5 mmHg) or in high purity Ar atmosphere (500 mmHg) at temperatures from 390 to 430°C, during 5 to 20 days. Platelets grew at 200-250 °C and perpendicular to the ampoule wall. Platelet size is up to 13×8 mm 2 and their thickness is from 50 to 100 μm. Crystals were characterized by optical microscopy, atomic force microscopy, scanning electron microscopy and low temperature photoluminescence. These characterizations showed that platelets have an exceptional transparence, that they grew from hexagonal grains and that their surface has a mean roughness of 4.6 nm. Low temperature photoluminescence was performed: peak position and broadness confirmed the high purity of the starting material and bands confirmed strong components from free and bonded excitons and low superficial imperfections ((Iex/Iimp)=6). Electrical properties were measured by fabricating radiation detectors with front palladium thermal deposition contacts and acrylic encapsulation. Resistivities of about 5 × 10 13 Ω. cm and current densities of 50 pA/cm 2 (10 V) were obtained. X-ray spectroscopy was performed with lead iodide detectors and an energy resolution of 1.2 keV was achieved for 241Am 18 keV radiation. Correlation between optical and surface properties and electrical parameters and detector performance are presented. Also, the different results were compared with previous ones for crystals grown by other methods and with alternative materials.

Authors: Tancredt G., Sosa A., Acosta E., Ceretta A.

Abstract: The efforts to discover NEOs have been concentrated up to now in the Northern Hemisphere where there are already 6 big NEO surveys functioning. The Observatorio Astronómico "Los Molinos" got a grant to install a new observatory fully dedicated to the NEO survey in the countryside of Uruguay (South America). The new telescope is expected to be operational in early 2002. The program is named "Búsqueda Uruguaya de Supernovas, Cometas y Asteroides - BUSCA".

Authors: Slomovitz D.
Title: Electronic system for increasing the accuracy of in-service instrument-current transformers

Abstract: An electronic compensator of ratio errors and phase-displacements is proposed for in-service transformers. Neither auxiliary winding nor auxiliary core is needed; and large variations of the burden connected to the secondary winding are admitted, as it is required by the standards.

Authors: Locquet A., Masoller C., Mégret P., Blondel M.
Title: Comparison of two types of synchronization of unidirectionally coupled external-cavity semiconductors lasers
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE-The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: GTL-CNRS Telecom, UMR CNRS 6603, Georgia Tech Lorraine, 2-3 Rue Marconi, 57070 Metz, France; Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Service d�Electromagnétisme et de Télécommunications, Faculté Polytechnique de Mons, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Locquet, A., GTL-CNRS Telecom, UMR CNRS 6603, Georgia Tech Lorraine, 2-3 Rue Marconi, 57070 Metz, France; Masoller, C., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; Mégret, P., Service d�Electromagnétisme et de Télécommunications, Faculté Polytechnique de Mons, Belgium; Blondel, M., Service d�Electromagnétisme et de Télécommunications, Faculté Polytechnique de Mons, Belgium
Abstract: We study numerically the synchronization regimes of optical-feedback-induced chaos in unidirectionally coupled semiconductor lasers. Depending on the operating conditions, the receiver laser intensity, IR(t), synchronizes with the intensity of the optically injected field, IT(t-τc) where τc is the flight time from the transmitter laser to the receiver laser, or synchronizes with IT(t-τc+τ), where τ is the external-cavity round-trip time. In the latter case, the intensity produced by the receiver anticipates the injected intensity IT(t-τc) by an anticipation time equal to τ. We find that synchronization with a lag time τc-τ is much more sensitive to frequency detuning and noise than synchronization with a lag time τc. Moreover, we also find that though synchronization with a lag time τc can be obtained using either an external-cavity or an open-loop receiver, the synchronization quality is always better when an external-cavity receiver is used. © 2002 SPIE · 0277-786X/02/$15.00.

Authors: Slomovitz D., Faverio C., Spaggiari A.
Title: A thermal voltage converter based on thermistors
Source title: CPEM Digest (Conference on Precision Electromagnetic Measurements)
Affiliations: UTE Laboratory, Paraguay 2385, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Slomovitz, D., UTE Laboratory, Paraguay 2385, Montevideo, Uruguay; Faverio, C., UTE Laboratory, Paraguay 2385, Montevideo, Uruguay; Spaggiari, A., UTE Laboratory, Paraguay 2385, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: It is presented a Thermal Voltage Converter (TVC) using thermistors as temperature detectors instead of thermocouples, as it is commonly used. Thermistors have the advantage of their high temperature coefficients. This permits to operate at low working temperature. In this way, main causes of AC/DC errors are reduced.

Authors: Slomovitz Daniel
Title: Electronic device for increasing the accuracy of high-voltage measuring transformers
Source title: CPEM Digest (Conference on Precision Electromagnetic Measurements)
Affiliations: UTE Laboratorio, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Slomovitz, Daniel, UTE Laboratorio, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: A new electronic system to assist high-voltage measuring transformers is proposed. This system compensates the voltage drops in the series impedances, which are the main cause of error in this type of transformers. An adjustment procedure is proposed using a power analyzer as the zero detector. The nonlinear behavior of the magnetizing branch has no influence on the results.

Authors: Hernandez Fernando, Gatti Edmundo, Garcia Luis
Title: Electromagnetic compatibility in active telephone sets
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility
Affiliations: ANTEL & Facultad de Ingenieria, (IIE), Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Hernandez, Fernando, ANTEL & Facultad de Ingenieria, (IIE), Montevideo, Uruguay; Gatti, Edmundo, ANTEL & Facultad de Ingenieria, (IIE), Montevideo, Uruguay; Garcia, Luis, ANTEL & Facultad de Ingenieria, (IIE), Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Dramatic growth take place nowadays in modern telecommunication equipment. The AM and FM radio transmitters power is very high and it affects the telephone sets performance. In the worst case subscribers sited near the transmission towers cannot hear the other talking part nor even dial the desired number. Usually they have to switch their sets to pulse dial mode in order to communicate. Three Mercosur Institutions (CITEI, IIE & ANTEL) have joint efforts to solve the problems existing in the PTT's outside plant (OSP). The studies results define measurement techniques and threshold values needed to achieve an adequate electromagnetic compatibility in active telephone sets and also determine a technical procedure to proper OSP construction. This paper describes the measurement techniques, test procedures and limits values used in the Mercosur region.

Abstract: The crystal structure of the system PrjMi-4BaCuOsFe has been recently reviewed. Tfie magnetic structure of samples with x = 0 aiidx = 1 is mainly due to effective local moments of iron and copper. In Pr-rich samples, Fe ions occupy two non-equivalent positions, making it substantially plausible that two or more magnetic subsets might coexist in the system. This contribution presents magnetization studies on five samples of the PrjMi. xBaCuOsFe system (x = 0. 0, 0. 2, 0. 5, 0. 7 and 1. 0). All samples exhibit a strong irreversible behavior between zero-fieldcooled and field-cooled procedures below a certain irreversibility temperature 7-4 Above Tk both branches are coincident and well described by a Curie-Weiss fitting. Decreasing the temperature below TJ, the zero-βeld-cooled response increases less than the field-cooled curve, indicating some degree of frustrated antiferromagnelic couplings. © 1999 Trans Tech Publications,.

Authors: Dubra A., Ferrari J.A., Frins E.M., Lezama A., Masoller C.
Title: Laser and optics in Uruguay
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Dubra, A., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Ferrari, J.A., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Frins, E.M., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Lezama, A., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Masoller, C., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Several researches in lasers and optics that include nonlinear optic spectroscopy, applied optics and theoretical modeling of the dynamics of semiconductor lasers are presented. The atom-laser interaction were carried out using diode lasers and rubidium atoms under different conditions. The use of degenerate four-wave mixing intensity noise fluctuations as a spectroscopic tool for the study of atomic dynamics were explored. The research of the applied optics groups involves the following: fiber characterization; step interferometry; optical fiber sensing; Fourier optics; and topological phase techniques. The nonlinear phenomena and chaotic behavior induced the optical feedback on the dynamics of semiconductor lasers were investigated.

Authors: Reginensi S., Palacios J., Martinez L.P., Keller J.
Title: Thin layer chromatography (TLC) of exopolysaccharide from Rhizobium phaseoli FES-C1 [Analisis por cromatografia en capa fina (TLC) de un exopolisacarido producido por Rhizobium phaseoli FES-C1]
Source title: Informacion Tecnologica
Affiliations: Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Reginensi, S., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Palacios, J., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Martinez, L.P., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Keller, J., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: The objective of this work was to determine the chemical composition of saccharide monomers of exopolysaccharide from Rhizobium phaseoli FES-C1 using thin layer chromatography (TLC). Samples of the polysaccharide were purified by acid hydrolysis carried out at 121°C. The monomeric polymer composition was detected using different solvent systems. The methylated fraction of exopolysaccharide was analyzed by TLC and was developed with sulfuric acid in ethanol. The TLC results show that the high molecular weight polymer is formed by glucose (RF = 0.30), glucuronic acid (RF = 0.19) and galactose (RF = 0.29). The methylated fraction of low molecular weight is a homopolymer with a degree of polymerization of 17. It is finally concluded from the study that the exopolysaccharide identified by TLC is a mixture of an homopolymer (glucose) and of heteropolymers (glucose, glucuronic acid, galactose).

Authors: Nesmachnow S., López A., López C.
Title: Towards proactive network load management for distributed parallel programming
Source title: LANOMS 1999 - 1st Latin American Network Operations and Management Symposium, Proceedings
Affiliations: Centro de Cálculo, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Nesmachnow, S., Centro de Cálculo, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; López, A., Centro de Cálculo, Universidad de la República, Uruguay; López, C., Centro de Cálculo, Universidad de la República, Uruguay
Abstract: In order to increase the overall performance of distributed parallel programs running in a network of non-dedicated workstations, we have researched methods for improving load balancing in loosely coupled heterogeneous distributed systems. Current software designed to handle distributed applications does not focus on the problem of forecasting the computers future load. The software only dispatches the tasks assigning them either to an idle CPU (in dedicated networks) or to the lowest loaded one (in non-dedicated networks). Our approach tries to improve the standard dispatching strategies provided by both parallel languages and libraries, by implementing new dispatching criteria. It will choose the most suitable computer after forecasting the load of the individual machines based on current and historical data. Existing applications could take advantage of this new service with no extra changes but a recompilation. A fair comparison between different dispatching algorithms could only be done if they run over the same external network load conditions. In order to do so, a tool to arbitrarily replicate historical observations of load parameters while running the different strategies was developed. In this environment, the new algorithms are being tested and compared to verify the improvement over the dispatching strategy already available. The overall performance of the system was tested with in-house developed numerical models. The project reported here is connected with other efforts at CeCal devoted to make it easier for scientists and developers to gain advantage of parallel computing techniques using low cost components.

Authors: Curbelo Rosario
Title: Noisy fingerprint identification by artificial neural networks
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Curbelo, Rosario, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: The objective of this work is to experiment neural networks methodology on noisy fingerprint identification. Several models for fingerprint codification based on minutiae characteristics were designed and implemented in this work. The ENH pre-processing software was used and tested and several improvements were implemented. The Competitive Selective neural network MCSL was used in the codification procedure in all models. A fingerprint variants generation procedure was also designed and implemented. It was used to generate a training set composed of 12 samples of each fingerprint selected from the standard database NIST 14. An identification system based on the Spiking Bayesian neural network SPIKE was used to test all codification models. The model based on minutiae direction provided the best performance and achieved the correct identification of 50% of a 12 fingerprint test set. For this model, both a Backpropagation Multilayer Perceptron MLP/BP neural network and SPIKE were tested on six 11 fingerprint test sets. Identification system performance depends heavily on image quality and the ability of the pre-processing software to obtain reliable minutiae in spite of image noise. Nevertheless, fingerprint identification using fingerprint coding based on minutiae direction turned out to be quite successful with a small set of fingerprints.

Authors: Masoller C., Abraham N.B.
Title: Dynamics of vertical-cavity surface-emitting semiconductor lasers with polarization-isotropic optical feedback
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Masoller, C., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Abraham, N.B., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: We study the dynamics of a vertical-cavity surface-emitting laser (VCSEL) with polarization isotropic optical feedback using the San Miguel, Feng, and Moloney model, which considers the role of carrier spin dynamics in both the conduction and the valence bands. Two transitions coupled to right- and left- circularly polarized light are coupled by spin-flip processes, which are characterized by the spin relaxation rate, γs. With moderately strong optical feedback and close to the solitary laser threshold the laser dynamics depend significantly on the value of γs. For low spin relaxation rates the time-averaged intensity often shows abrupt dropouts, similar to those observed in edge-emitting semiconductor lasers. Underlying the dropouts there is antiphase competition between the time-averaged orthogonal linearly polarized components of the electric field. For large values of the spin relaxation rate the dropouts tend to disappear and the time-averaged intensity is constant or nearly constant, depending on the stability of the linearly polarized states of the laser without feedback.

Authors: Masoller C., Figliola A., Giudici M., Tredicce J.R., Abraham N.B.
Title: Wavelet analysis of low frequency fluctuations of a semiconductor laser
Source title: Optics Communications
Affiliations: Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la Repûblica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Instituto de Cálcula, FCEN, UBA, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Institut Non Lineaire de Nice, Univ. de Nice-Sophia-Antipolis, CNRS UMR, 06560 Valbonne, France; Department of Physics, Bryn Mawr College, 101 N. Merion Ave., Bryn Mawr, PA 19010-2899, United States
Authors with affiliations: Masoller, C., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la Repûblica, Montevideo, Uruguay, Department of Physics, Bryn Mawr College, 101 N. Merion Ave., Bryn Mawr, PA 19010-2899, United States; Figliola, A., Instituto de Cálcula, FCEN, UBA, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Giudici, M., Instituto de Cálcula, FCEN, UBA, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Tredicce, J.R., Institut Non Lineaire de Nice, Univ. de Nice-Sophia-Antipolis, CNRS UMR, 06560 Valbonne, France; Abraham, N.B., Department of Physics, Bryn Mawr College, 101 N. Merion Ave., Bryn Mawr, PA 19010-2899, United States
Abstract: Wavelet transform analysis of experimentally measured intensity fluctuations distinguishes the transition from low frequency fluctuations at moderate feedback to stable operation at strong feedback. Comparison of these results with those of a wavelet analysis of lowpass filtered solutions of the Lang-Kobayashi equations for deterministic evolution of a single mode semiconductor laser with optical feedback finds substantial agreement in the part of the wavelet spectrum corresponding to slow dynamics. Substantial disagreement is found in the fast dynamics, which lessens when noise is added to the equations. © 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Teixeira Luis, Montana Juan, Losada Miguel
Title: Littoral processes in a prograding coast: The case study of the Atlantic Ocean coast of Uruguay
Source title: Proceedings of the Coastal Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Inst de Mecanica de los Fluidos e, Ingenieria Ambiental, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Teixeira, Luis, Inst de Mecanica de los Fluidos e, Ingenieria Ambiental, Montevideo, Uruguay; Montana, Juan, Inst de Mecanica de los Fluidos e, Ingenieria Ambiental, Montevideo, Uruguay; Losada, Miguel, Inst de Mecanica de los Fluidos e, Ingenieria Ambiental, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: The Atlantic Ocean coast of Uruguay extends from Punta del Este outer limit of the Rio de la Plata Estuary, to the Brazilian border, over 220 kms. This case study applies to a homogeneous coastal stretch of 80 kms long, north of Punta del Este. The main coastal features are three littoral lagoons, Jose Ignacio, Garzon and Rocha, whose mouths open and close by natural or antropic actions every year. The coastline is formed by 1-2 mm coarse sand on highly reflective beaches. Beach berm is overwashed by the SE storm waves. Landward there is a dune system. This beach-dune structure is approximately 100 m wide. At least three similar morphological structures may be landward identified, which were developed during a period of time when the sea level was about 5 m higher than today's sea level (approximately 5000 years BP). 14C technique applied to chalk samples shows a relative decrease of the sea level in the last 5000 years. Furthermore, gravimetric data shows that there is an anomaly, which supports the existence of an isostatic rise of the continental shelf. As a result, the Atlantic Ocean Coast of Uruguay is prograding. The beach coarse material is provided by the wave action from the continental shelf, while the fine dune material seems to be obtained from the erosion of the land weathered granite.

Authors: Oliver J.P., De Oliveira A.F., Acle J.P., De La Vega R.J., Canetti R.
Title: Implementation of adaptive logic networks on an FPGA board
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Instituto de Ingenieria Electrica, Facultad de Ingenieria, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Grupo Adqdat, Facultad de Ingenieria, Universidad Nacional del Centro, Olavarria - Bs. As., Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Oliver, J.P., Instituto de Ingenieria Electrica, Facultad de Ingenieria, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; De Oliveira, A.F., Instituto de Ingenieria Electrica, Facultad de Ingenieria, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Acle, J.P., Instituto de Ingenieria Electrica, Facultad de Ingenieria, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; De La Vega, R.J., Grupo Adqdat, Facultad de Ingenieria, Universidad Nacional del Centro, Olavarria - Bs. As., Argentina; Canetti, R., Instituto de Ingenieria Electrica, Facultad de Ingenieria, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: This work is part of a project that studies the implementation of neural network algorithms in reconfigurable hardware as a way to obtain a high performance neural processor. The results for Adaptive Logic Network (ALN) type binary networks with and without learning in hardware are presented. The designs were made on a hardware platform consisting of a PC compatible as the host computer and an ALTERA RIPP10 reconfigurable board with nine FLEX8K FPGAs and 512KB RAM. The different designs were run on the same hardware platform, taking advantage of its configurability. A software tool was developed to automatically convert the ALN network description resulting from the training process with the ATREE 2.7 for Windows software package into a hardware description file. This approach enables the easy generation of the hardware necessary to evaluate the very large combinatorial functions that results in an ALN. In an on-board learning version, an ALN basic node was designed optimizing it in the amount of cells per node used. Several nodes connected in a binary tree structure for each output bit, together with a control block, form the ALN network. The total amount of logic available on-board in the used platform limits the maximum size of the networks from a small to medium range. The performance was studied in pattern recognition applications. The results are compared with the software simulation of ALN networks.

Title: Overview of low-volume roads: Keynote address
Source title: Transportation Research Record
Affiliations: Min. of Transport and Public Works, Rincan 561, Montevideo, Uruguay
