Authors: Coleman W.P., Gaynicotche A., Mendoza S.M.
Title: Healthcare systems process reengineering for developing countries: A report to IMIA working group 9
Source title: Studies in Health Technology and Informatics
Affiliations: WPCMath, 130 Market Street, Annapolis MD, 21401, United States; Sociedad Uruguaya de Informatica en Salud, Montevideo, Uruguay; Red de Desarrollo Sostenible de Nicaragua, Managua, Nicaragua
Authors with affiliations: Coleman, W.P., WPCMath, 130 Market Street, Annapolis MD, 21401, United States; Gaynicotche, A., Sociedad Uruguaya de Informatica en Salud, Montevideo, Uruguay; Mendoza, S.M., Red de Desarrollo Sostenible de Nicaragua, Managua, Nicaragua
Abstract: To discover what kinds of health informatics the developing countries need, we look first to the underlying social structures that informatics is to support. Developing countries face severe problems in their goal of assuring access to quality healthcare to their citizens. Nor is it comforting to look to the example of the developed countries, themselves uncomfortable with the tremendous commitment of resources that they use. It seems clear that if developing countries are to succeed their systems for assuring health will need to achieve radical improvements over those currently employed by the developed countries. They need to build systems that are directed to the heart of the problems; they need to make the best use of their existing human and economic resources; and they need to do this while respecting the human potential and aspirations of their people. Any such system will need to be built around planning, organizing and measuring the long-term, rather than episodic, health of citizens. In particular, health interventions need to be moved upstream where they are more effective and less expensive. The job of health informatics is to provide the fundamental enabling infrastructure that would allow individuals to cooperate in the fluid, effective ways required. We describe some of the requisites for such a system. Certainly, its construction will depend on the use of an open, standardsbased distributed object software architecture. © 1998 IMIA. All rights reserved.

Authors: Fernandez Jorge, Mandl Walter, Slomovitz Daniel, Trigo Leonardo
Title: New diagnostic techniques for large utility generators
Source title: Conference Record of IEEE International Symposium on Electrical Insulation
Affiliations: UTE Lab, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Fernandez, Jorge, UTE Lab, Montevideo, Uruguay; Mandl, Walter, UTE Lab, Montevideo, Uruguay; Slomovitz, Daniel, UTE Lab, Montevideo, Uruguay; Trigo, Leonardo, UTE Lab, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: For many years the diagnostic techniques used for the assessment of the insulation condition of high voltage generators was based on the determination of several traditional dielectric parameters. The detection of partial discharge activity in the insulation can give a closer knowledge of the defects in stator winding insulation. In the past few years digital techniques for the acquisition of the partial discharge signals have been developed. The statistical processing of this data allows a better understanding of the phenomena in the insulation. In this paper a digital implementation of a method for the measurement of partial discharges is shown. Conventional digital oscilloscopes can be used as an interesting alternative instead of using expensive dedicated electronics. A software package has been developed for the statistical analysis of the discharges. In the past few years new parameters have been used. The software calculates these meters from the statistical analysis in order to make a more precise diagnostic of the insulation condition. The system has been used during field tests in different types of generators and also in laboratory tests. The calibration of the measuring system and its related problems are discussed. Electronic pulse generators are commonly used for the calibration of the system but in complex systems many new problems arise. The reflection and attenuation of pulses make it difficult for the system to correctly detect the discharges.

Authors: Coirolo Alejandro
Title: Recovery of generator insulation
Source title: Conference Record of IEEE International Symposium on Electrical Insulation
Affiliations: Rambla Edison s/n, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Coirolo, Alejandro, Rambla Edison s/n, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: During 1992, in Central Batlle, a Thermal Power Plant placed in Montevideo burnt by an accident, which caused a great damage in Turbine Number Five (88 MVA) and Number Six (156 MVA). Worst damage took place in Turbine No.6, Turbine No.5 was only affected by the smoke resultant of burning cables. UTE (Electrical Enterprise which belongs to the State) decided to rebuilt both Units, which were modernized with new control and electric equipment. During the repair of Unit No.5, one of the most important tasks, was to change the retaining rings of the generator rotor. When we took out the rotor and the old retaining rings, we inspected both stator and rotor, finding a lot of problems. UTE decided to repair these faults, before putting the unit in service again, since those problems compromised the reliability. This paper deals with the description of all the tasks done and how our personnel managed to repair the generator of Unit No.5, which is a critical backup for Montevideo's electric system.

Authors: Núñez I., Negreira C., Ferrari J.
Title: Acoustic field imaging by light reflection at the free surface of a liquid
Source title: Ultrasonics
Affiliations: Lab. de Ultrasonido, Inst. de Física, Fac. de Ciencias, T. Narvaja 1674, Montevideo, Uruguay; Inst. de Física, Fac. de Ingeniería, C. C. 30, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Núñez, I., Lab. de Ultrasonido, Inst. de Física, Fac. de Ciencias, T. Narvaja 1674, Montevideo, Uruguay; Negreira, C., Lab. de Ultrasonido, Inst. de Física, Fac. de Ciencias, T. Narvaja 1674, Montevideo, Uruguay; Ferrari, J., Inst. de Física, Fac. de Ingeniería, C. C. 30, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: In this paper we present a novel technique for acoustic field imaging. This technique is based on reflection of a collimated laser beam at the free surface of a liquid. The reflected beam becomes phase modulated by the acoustic wave as in acoustical holographic systems. We do not use a reference acoustical beam for holographic reconstruction but we observe this phase modulation using dark-field techniques. It gives a measurement of the acoustic field power as a function of the position. The authors have built an optical imaging system and carried out experiments with piezocomposite transducers. The technique presented in this work is able to give fast quantitative information about the performance of individual ceramic rods of the piezocomposite. © 1998 Elsevier Science B.V.

Authors: Carrasco J., Rodriguez R., Rondoni A., Pardo A.
Title: Improvement of quality service in Uruguay - plans developed and its results in the period 93-95. Fault statistic as a parameter of measurement
Source title: IEE Conference Publication
Affiliations: U.T.E., Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Carrasco, J., U.T.E., Uruguay; Rodriguez, R., U.T.E., Uruguay; Rondoni, A., U.T.E., Uruguay; Pardo, A., U.T.E., Uruguay
Abstract: The present paper aims to describe the improvement process of the quality of the product and the technical service that has been undertaken in UTE since 1990 and to show the obtained results so far as well as the actions foreseen to future. First it develops the institutional frame and the country context in which the activity of UTE is developed. About the Technical Service it describes the original situation for the process of improvement (1990) and carries out a summary of it and the actions that have been taken with the creation of the PMD (Distribution Improvement Plans). In addition the system for the quality control is developed. It is structured based on global and individual indexes supported by the corporate centralized and distributed informatic tools that the company possess. This control system has allowed to carry out a pursuit of the relative evolution of the quality year to year and to establish absolute comparisons with companies from the Region and from Europe. The current situation and the improvement for Montevideo, capital city of Uruguay, are described. Finally, the work contains a brief description of the plans and actions that UTE is developing facing to the changes of environment that the approval of the Regulative Frame for the electric activity could produce.

Authors: Darscht P., Pereira C.E.
Title: Modeling computer-based real-time systems: Which views do we need?
Source title: Control Engineering Practice
Affiliations: Instituto de Ingenieria Electrica, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Darscht, P., Instituto de Ingenieria Electrica, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Pereira, C.E., Instituto de Ingenieria Electrica, Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: In order to manage complexity during the life-cycle of computer-based real-time systems, it is usual to consider the system being developed from many different perspectives. In order to reflect this, models are constructed as a composite of many different modeling views. In this paper the modeling views used during the early stages of the object-oriented development process of real-time systems are classified according to their contents and their granularity. The taxonomy thus obtained is used to evaluate current object-oriented analysis methods that are being used in real-time applications.In order to manage complexity during the life-cycle of computer-based real-time systems, it is usual to consider the system being developed from many different perspectives. In order to reflect this, models are constructed as a composite of many different modeling views. In this paper the modeling views used during the early stages of the object-oriented development process of real-time systems are classified according to their contents and their granularity. The taxonomy thus obtained is used to evaluate current object-oriented analysis methods that are being used in real-time applications.

Authors: Nunez I., Negreira C.
Title: Detection of evanescent acoustical waves on water surface by using defocusing optical method
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Ultrasonics Symposium
Affiliations: Inst de Fisica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Nunez, I., Inst de Fisica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Negreira, C., Inst de Fisica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: The acoustical perturbation by targets smaller than wavelength generates evanescent waves which decay with the distance of propagation. By putting such targets immediately under the free surface of water, the diffracted acoustical field can excite the surface membrane before to evanesce, and produces a static ripple because the radiation pressure. A collimated beam of light reflects at the perturbed surface and it becomes modulated in phase. In this work we present a numerical calculus of the optical image produced by the ultrasonic field diffracted from a target array-like. The spatial periodicity of such array is smaller than the acoustical wavelength. We also show experimental results where we achieve an optical image of the acoustical evanescent waves produced by the target. With this method we look for a spatial resolution smaller than acoustical wavelength (Rayleigh criterion). In our experimental device we use a sound wavelength in water greater than 1.5 mm, generated by a PZT transducer. We can resolve an array of 1.0 mm of periodicity.

Authors: Sensale B., Partridge P.W., Creus G.J.
Title: Dual reciprocity boundary element method in viscoelasticity
Source title: Proceedings of the World Conference on the Boundary Element Method, BEM
Affiliations: Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Sensale, B., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Partridge, P.W., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Creus, G.J., Universidad de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: The Boundary Element Method is combined with the Dual Reciprocity Method to analyse aging viscoelastic structures; the general theoretical formulation, the description of numerical algorithms and some examples are given.

Authors: Cassina J.C., Gonzalez A.R., Guerra-Machado I.
Title: Geometric characteristics of weld beads deposited by the pulsed GTAW process [Caracteristicas geometricas de cordones de soldadura depositados por proceso tig con corriente pulsante]
Source title: Informacion Tecnologica
Affiliations: Univ de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Cassina, J.C., Univ de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Gonzalez, A.R., Univ de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay; Guerra-Machado, I., Univ de la Republica, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: A factorial design has been applied to experimentally study the effect of several variables of the pulse GTAW process on weld bead continuity. Parameters such as peak current, peak time and welding speed were considered and the effects of mean current, mean power and welding energy on weld bead penetration were analyzed. Results show that mean current and mean power are the controlling factors of weld bead penetration. However, penetration is directly related to the welding energy, independent of the welding speed. Thus, the welding energy is a more appropriate parameter for determining weld penetration.

Authors: Negreira C.A., Gomez H., Aulet A., Eiras J.A., Bassora L.A.
Title: Analysis of cross-coupling characteristics of piezocomposites 1-3
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Ultrasonics Symposium
Affiliations: Universidad de la Republica, -Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Negreira, C.A., Universidad de la Republica, -Montevideo, Uruguay; Gomez, H., Universidad de la Republica, -Montevideo, Uruguay; Aulet, A., Universidad de la Republica, -Montevideo, Uruguay; Eiras, J.A., Universidad de la Republica, -Montevideo, Uruguay; Bassora, L.A., Universidad de la Republica, -Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Some of the problems of developing a 1-3 piezocomposite for medical and NDT imaging are examined. In the case of piezocomposites plates, lateral resonances are generated by multiple Bragg scattering of Lamb waves. Plates samples in polyurethane - PZT5A have been prepared with a ceramic square rod geometry. The individual elements are excited by electrical and ultrasound pulses. The electrical cross-coupling characteristics are analysed. We identified two separate cross-coupling waves. These experimental results are compared with there obtained with an acoustic measurements at the received waves by neighbours elements of the excited. In this paper we can clearly see the origin at each lateral waves which produce the multiple Bragg scattering.

Authors: Nunez I., Negreira C., Ferrari J.
Title: Amplitude measurements of acoustic fields by light reflection at the free surface of a liquid
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Ultrasonics Symposium
Affiliations: Inst de Fisica. Fac. de Ciencias, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Nunez, I., Inst de Fisica. Fac. de Ciencias, Montevideo, Uruguay; Negreira, C., Inst de Fisica. Fac. de Ciencias, Montevideo, Uruguay; Ferrari, J., Inst de Fisica. Fac. de Ciencias, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: A novel technique for amplitude measurements of acoustic field by light reflection at the free surface of a liquid is presented. The motion of the boundary layer of the liquid induced by the acoustic pressure, modulates the phase of a collimated laser beam. This phase modulation is observed using dark-ground techniques, and it gives a measurement of the acoustic power as function of the position. Experiments with piezocomposite 1-3 transducers were carried out. The technique presented in this work is able to give quickly quantitative information about the motion of individual ceramic rods of the piezocomposite, and allow a fast quality control for piezocomposite 1-3 transducers. We achieved a lateral resolution of 0.2 × 0.4 mm. The theoretical limit for the axial resolution is of few Angstroms.

Authors: González R., Gómez D., Ferro Fontan C., Sicardi Schifino A.C., Montagne R.
Title: Cascading process in the flute-mode turbulence of a plasma
Source title: Physics of Fluids B
Affiliations: Departamento de Fisica, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, (1428) Buenos Aires, Argentina; Instituto de Astronomía y Fisica del Espacio, C C No. 67, Sucursal 28, (1428) Buenos Aires, Argentina; Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, CC 10773, CP 11200, Montevideo, Uruguay; Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingenieria, Universidad de la República, CC No. 30, CP 11000, Montevideo, Uruguay; Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii, 2680 Woodlawn Drive, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States; Universitat de Les Illes Balears, Departement de Física, E-07071, Palma de Mallorca, Spain
Authors with affiliations: González, R., Departamento de Fisica, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, (1428) Buenos Aires, Argentina, Instituto de Astronomía y Fisica del Espacio, C C No. 67, Sucursal 28, (1428) Buenos Aires, Argentina; Gómez, D., Departamento de Fisica, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, (1428) Buenos Aires, Argentina, Instituto de Astronomía y Fisica del Espacio, C C No. 67, Sucursal 28, (1428) Buenos Aires, Argentina, Institute for Astronomy, University of Hawaii, 2680 Woodlawn Drive, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States; Ferro Fontan, C., Departamento de Fisica, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Universidad de Buenos Aires, (1428) Buenos Aires, Argentina, Instituto de Astronomía y Fisica del Espacio, C C No. 67, Sucursal 28, (1428) Buenos Aires, Argentina; Sicardi Schifino, A.C., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, CC 10773, CP 11200, Montevideo, Uruguay, Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingenieria, Universidad de la República, CC No. 30, CP 11000, Montevideo, Uruguay; Montagne, R., Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de la República, CC 10773, CP 11200, Montevideo, Uruguay, Instituto de Física, Facultad de Ingenieria, Universidad de la República, CC No. 30, CP 11000, Montevideo, Uruguay, Universitat de Les Illes Balears, Departement de Física, E-07071, Palma de Mallorca, Spain
Abstract: The cascades of ideal invariants in the flute-mode turbulence are analyzed by considering a statistics based on an elementary three-mode coupling process. The statistical dynamics of the system is investigated on the basis of the existence of the physically most important (PMI) triad. When finite ion Larmor radius effects are considered, the PMI triad describes the formation of zonal flows. © 1993 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Groisman U.
Title: Computer program for automatic grid generation in ducts wiith varying cross section and curved axis
Affiliations: Inst of Fluid Mechanics and, Environmental Engineering, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Groisman, U., Inst of Fluid Mechanics and, Environmental Engineering, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: A computer program to generate automatically a finite difference mesh in a duct with varying cross section and curved axis, is presented. Spline interpolation for surface fitting and multisurface method to connect them, are used to generate a relatively simple and fast method.

Authors: Duomarco J.L., Tierno J.E.
Title: Synthesis of time series for the clearness index using a reordering algorithm
Source title: Il Nuovo Cimento C
Affiliations: Instituto de Física, Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, C.C. 30, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Duomarco, J.L., Instituto de Física, Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, C.C. 30, Montevideo, Uruguay; Tierno, J.E., Instituto de Física, Instituto de Ingeniería Eléctrica, Facultad de Ingeniería, C.C. 30, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Two insolation series, 4 and 8 years long, collected in different sites of the country, are used to contrast the behaviour of a statistical model for the clearness index, developed by the authors. This model is based on the independence between the stationary and the sequential statistic of clearness index series. A set of prospective clearness index coefficients is reordered until acquiring the sequential behaviour. A computer code has been developed to this end. © 1991 Società Italiana di Fisica.

Authors: Savio E., Kremer C., Gambino D., Kremer E., Leon A.
Title: Electrolytic 99mTcO4 - reduction: A different pathway to obtain 99mTc-labelled compounds
Source title: International Journal of Radiation Applications and Instrumentation. Part
Affiliations: Cátedra de Radioquímica Montevideo, Uruguay; Cátedra de Química Inorgánica, Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, General Flores 2124, Casilla Correo, 1157 Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Savio, E., Cátedra de Radioquímica Montevideo, Uruguay; Kremer, C., Cátedra de Radioquímica Montevideo, Uruguay; Gambino, D., Cátedra de Radioquímica Montevideo, Uruguay; Kremer, E., Cátedra de Radioquímica Montevideo, Uruguay; Leon, A., Cátedra de Radioquímica Montevideo, Uruguay, Cátedra de Química Inorgánica, Facultad de Química, Universidad de la República, General Flores 2124, Casilla Correo, 1157 Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: Electrolytic reduction of 99mTcO4 - at inert electrodes to obtain 99mTc cationic complexes and in vitro stability of labelled compounds were studied. Amines were used as neutral N-donor ligands and a systematic analysis of various parameters involved in the reduction process was performed. Usefulness of electrolytic reduction was proved as an alternative 99mTc-labelling method. Its most important advantages are: production of complexes with a high radiochemical purity, negligible presence of red-hyd-99mTc, lack of foreign materials, simplicity of development and possibility of further applications. © 1991.

Authors: Hareau A., Sztern D., Trovero Daniel G., Gonzalez E., Motta B., Trobo C.
Title: Solid wastes in Uruguay: resource recovery in experimental areas
Source title: International Conference on Environmental Pollution
Affiliations: Manuel Oribe Inst, Montevideo, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Hareau, A., Manuel Oribe Inst, Montevideo, Uruguay; Sztern, D., Manuel Oribe Inst, Montevideo, Uruguay; Trovero, Daniel G., Manuel Oribe Inst, Montevideo, Uruguay; Gonzalez, E., Manuel Oribe Inst, Montevideo, Uruguay; Motta, B., Manuel Oribe Inst, Montevideo, Uruguay; Trobo, C., Manuel Oribe Inst, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: This document describes solid waste recycling in three experimental areas in Uruguay. Social and working conditions of the people involved as well as recycling methods and wastes composition are considered. The environmental impact of waste disposal and recycling activities in the study areas is addressed. The main relevant legal and economic issues are discussed. The experience carried out by the two existing cooperativas in mentioned. Action to be taken in order to improve recycling conditions is eventually proposed.

Authors: Grompone J., Brum F., Casamayor M.
Title: Declarative language for data and telex exchange configuration
Source title: IEE Conference Publication
Affiliations: Interfase Ltd, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Grompone, J., Interfase Ltd, Uruguay; Brum, F., Interfase Ltd, Uruguay; Casamayor, M., Interfase Ltd, Uruguay
Abstract: The traditional method used for the configuration of a telecommunications exchange, irrespective of its purpose, is to have a set of programs and procedures -in most cases not particularly friendly-which are used for the painstaking job of assembling the tables required for internal use. This involves training technicians obliged to work with codes, and quite frequently the equipment is discontinued before users have learned to handle the configuration techniques properly. The LEP language is a simple, declarative language designed to define the routing and customizing rules of a telex exchange, but the concepts employed can easily be applied to telephony or data transmission. This paper discusses the general abstraction used in this language based on the present packet switching experience. The lexical, syntactic and semantic details are not described here and the examples are rather informal.

Authors: Tichy Mario, Alexandrovitz Abraham
Title: New open-loop starting strategy for line-commutated three-phase brigde inverters in battery storage plants [New open-loop starting strategy for line-commutated three-phase bridge inverters in battery storage plants]
Source title: ETZ-Archiv
Affiliations: Univ de la Republica O. del Uruguay, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Tichy, Mario, Univ de la Republica O. del Uruguay, Uruguay; Alexandrovitz, Abraham, Univ de la Republica O. del Uruguay, Uruguay
Abstract: When a battery energy storage plant is used as an emergency power supply in an AC system, it should be started, and steady state reached as rapidly as possible. This paper presents a new method that enables this requirement to be met, using a line-commutated three-phase bridge inverter. It is shown how a thyristor firing

Authors: Guarga R., Rodal E., Garcia J., Sanchez A., Solorio A., Cafaggi A.
Title: Some fundamental characteristics of oscillatory swirling flows in cylindrical tubes and cones
Source title: Boletin de la Facultad de Ingenieria y Agrimensura de Montevideo
Affiliations: Univ de la Republica, Uruguay
Authors with affiliations: Guarga, R., Univ de la Republica, Uruguay; Rodal, E., Univ de la Republica, Uruguay; Garcia, J., Univ de la Republica, Uruguay; Sanchez, A., Univ de la Republica, Uruguay; Solorio, A., Univ de la Republica, Uruguay; Cafaggi, A., Univ de la Republica, Uruguay
Abstract: A theoretical model of the swirling flow confined in a cylindrical tube is developed. The theoretical model is compared with pressure, velocity and oscillatory behaviors experimental data and the variables; rotational core radius, the swirl decay rate, the dimensionless shear stress on the core, are defined and calculated. The model is applied to explain the different location that the flow axial symmetry loss has in cylindrical tubes compared with divergent cones. The paper reports about the first results obtained in the way of understanding the fundamental phenomena that the industrial draft tube oscillatory behavior presents. The main purpose of the work is to understand the fundamental characteristics of this type of flows and to apply them to the draft tube vortex that appears in Francis turbines when they operate out of the design range.
